problems.title: 2019 A/NT1: A Geometric Progression
problems.text: Let $a_1$, $a_2$, $\ldots$, $a_n$ be a geometric progression with $a_1 = \sqrt{2}$ and $a_2 = \sqrt[3]{3}$. What is \[\displaystyle{\frac{a_1+a_{2013}}{a_7+a_{2019}}}?\]
problems.solution:
Let the value of the common ratio of the sequence be $r$. The given quantity is then equal to

$$\frac{a_1+a_{2013}}{r^6(a_1+a_{2013})}=\frac{1}{r^6}.$$We can then compute $r$ as the ratio of the second term to the first term, so

$$\frac{1}{r^6}=\frac{(\sqrt{2})^6}{(\sqrt[3]{3})^6}=\boxed{\frac{8}{9}}.$$

problems.title: 2019 A/NT2: Fraction is Not an Integer
problems.text: For all positive integers $n$, let $f(n)$ return the smallest positive integer $k$ for which $\tfrac{n}{k}$ is not an integer.  For example, $f(6) = 4$ because $1$, $2$, and $3$ all divide $6$ but $4$ does not.  Determine the largest possible value of $f(n)$ as $n$ ranges over the set $\{1,2,\ldots, 3000\}$.
problems.solution: Calculate $12 \# = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 = 2310.$ Note that for prime factorized $n = \prod_{j = 1}^k p_j^{e_j}$ we have $f(n) = \min\left(p_1^{e_1 + 1}, p_2^{e_2 + 1}, \cdots , p_k^{e_k + 1}, q\right),$ where $q$ is the smallest prime that does not divide $n.$ The upper bound on $f(n)$ is thus $q,$ so we want all the $p_j^{e_j + 1} \geq q.$ Also, $q \leq 11$ because $13 \# > 3000.$ We have established $q = 11$ as an upper bound; the number $n = 2^3 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 = 2520$ shows that $f(2520) = \boxed{11}$ is the maximum.

problems.title: 2019 A/NT3: The Annual Polynomial Problem
problems.text: Let $P(x)$ be a quadratic polynomial with real coefficients such that $P(3) = 7$ and \[P(x) = P(0) + P(1)x + P(2)x^2\]for all real $x$.  What is $P(-1)$?
problems.solution:
Let $P(x)=ax^2+bx+c$. Then $P(0)=c,P(1)=b,P(2)=a$ gives the three equations $c=c, a+b+c=b, 4a+2b+c=a$. The second equation gives $a=-c$. Substituting into the third equation gives $b=c$.



Thus, $P(x)=-cx^2+cx+c$. Since $P(3)=7$, $P(3)=-9c+3c+c=-5c=7$, so $c=-\frac{7}{5}$. Thus, $P(-1)=-c=\boxed{\frac{7}{5}}$.

problems.title: 2019 A/NT4: Greatest Common Divisor is Three
problems.text: Determine the sum of all positive integers $n$ between $1$ and $100$ inclusive such that \[\gcd(n,2^n - 1) = 3.\]
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247CarefulFrom the given, we see that $3|n.$ Also, since $2^n \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ we get that $2|n,$ so $6|n.$ However, we must make sure that $\left(n, 2^n - 1\right)$ can never be greater than 3.



If $2^n - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$ then $4|n.$ So, if $4, 5|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum. There is only one such $n = 60.$

If $2^n - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$ then $6|n.$ So, if $6, 7|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum. The values of such $n$ are $n = 42, 84.$

If $2^n - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{9}$ then $6|n.$ So, if $6, 9|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum. The values of such $n$ are $n = 18, 36, 54, 72, 90.$



Summing from all $n \in [1, 100]$ we get $$\sum n = \sum_{k= 1}^{16}6k - (60 + 42 + 84 + 18 + 36 + 54 + 72 + 90) = \boxed{360}.$$

problems.title: 2019 A/NT5: Two Less than a Square
problems.text: Let $x_n$ be the smallest positive integer such that $7^n$ divides $x_n^2-2$. Find $x_1+x_2+x_3$.
problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247Mod BashWe solve the three equations $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{7, 49, 343}.$ The first two can easily be guessed to give $x_1 = 3, x_2 = 10.$ However, note that $x \equiv 3, 4 \pmod{7},$ so write them as $x = 7a + 3, 7b + 4.$ Substitute each of these into $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{49}$ to get $a \equiv 1 \pmod{7}, b \equiv 5 \pmod{7}.$ Now write $a = 7c + 1, b = 7d + 5$ to get $x = 49c + 10, 49d + 39.$ Substitute $x = 49c + 10$ into $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{343}$ to get $c \equiv 2 \pmod{7} \iff c = 7e + 2 \iff x = 343e + 108.$ Now, check $x = 39, 88$ to see that none of them are congruent to $2 \pmod{343}$ so $x_3 = 108.$ Sum to get $\boxed{121}.$

problems.title: 2019 A/NT6: The Obligatory Vieta Problem
problems.text:
Let $a, b$ and $c$ be the distinct solutions to the equation $x^3-2x^2+3x-4=0$. Find the value of

$$\frac{1}{a(b^2+c^2-a^2)}+\frac{1}{b(c^2+a^2-b^2)}+\frac{1}{c(a^2+b^2-c^2)}.$$
problems.solution:
Y by SHARKYBOY, flyrain, Williamgolly, Adventure10, Mango247vieta'sWe rewrite the sum as $$\sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(P_2 - 2a^2)}$$where we define $P_2 = a^2 + b^2 + c^2$. By a computation involving symmetric sums of the roots we can easily see that $P_2 = -2$, so the sum factors as $$-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(1+a^2)}$$One can now perform partial fractions on this summand (by breaking it into fractions with denominators $a, a + i, a - i$ and compute the resulting cyclic sums easily using the given information - and the sum inside should evaluate to $\frac{3}{4} - \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2} = - \frac{1}{4}$, giving a final answer of $\boxed{\frac{1}{8}}$.

remarkIn competition, I made a mistake and ended up with the sum $$-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(1-a^2)}$$without realizing this was actually wrong. It turns out the answer is invariant of this issue, most likely due to the fact that the complex phase factors must eventually cancel if all the symmetric sums are real (or something like that). This computation was a little easier to do (because I didn't have to carry the $i$s around) but even though I haven't done this explicit computation since I don't think it would be much worse.

problems.title: 2019 A/NT7: Sum of Phis and Squares of Floors
problems.text:
For all positive integers $n$, let

\[f(n) = \sum_{k=1}^n\varphi(k)\left\lfloor\frac nk\right\rfloor^2.\]Compute $f(2019) - f(2018)$.  Here $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ which are relatively prime to $n$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Misplaced IMORewrite $f(2019) - f(2018)$ as $$\sum_{k = 1}^{2018}\varphi(k)\left(\left\lfloor\dfrac{2019}{k}\right\rfloor ^2 - \left\lfloor \dfrac{2018}{k} \right\rfloor ^2 \right) + \varphi(2019).$$Note that the difference of floor functions is nonzero if and only if $k|2019, k < 2019$ and $k$ does not divide 2018. Since $(2019, 2018) = 1$ the condition simplifies down to $k|2019, k < 2019.$ To see this, write $2018 = qk + r$ using Euclidean division and note that $\left\lfloor \frac{2019}{k} \right \rfloor = \left\lfloor q + \frac{r + 1}{k} \right\rfloor > \left\lfloor \frac{2018}{k} \right\rfloor = q \iff r + 1 = k.$ This gives us three such values of $k: 1, 3, 673.$ Thus, $f(2019) - f(2018) = \varphi(1)\left(2019^2 - 2018^2\right) + \varphi(3)\left(673^2 - 672^2\right) + \varphi(673)\left(3^2 - 2^2\right) + \varphi(2019) = \boxed{11431}.$

problems.title: 2019 A/NT8: Transformation of Roots of Unity
problems.text: It is given that the roots of the polynomial $P(z) = z^{2019} - 1$ can be written in the form $z_k = x_k + iy_k$ for $1\leq k\leq 2019$.  Let $Q$ denote the monic polynomial with roots equal to $2x_k + iy_k$ for $1\leq k\leq 2019$.  Compute $Q(-2)$.
problems.solution:
Let the roots be $e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}}.$  Notice that

$$Re(e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}})=\frac{e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}}+e^{\frac{-2ki\pi}{2019}}}{2}.$$

Now, manipulating some exponents and factoring, we see that the value we seek si



$$\prod_{k=1}^{2018} (\frac{-4z_k-3z_k^2-1}{2z_k})=(-1)\prod_{k=1}^{2018} (\frac{(3z_k+1)(z_k+1)}{2z_k}),$$

where $z_k$ is a 2019th root of unity.  Now, evaluating each term separate and seeing that the answer is $$\frac{(-1)(T(-1/3))(T(-1))}{2^{2019}}$$

where $T(z) = z^{2019}-1,$



the answer is $\frac{-1-3^{2019}}{2^{2018}}.$

problems.title: 2019 A/NT10: All Coefficients Divisible by n
problems.text:
Let $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ which are relatively prime to $n$.  Determine the number of positive integers $2\leq n\leq 50$ such that all coefficients of the polynomial

\[
\left(x^{\varphi(n)} - 1\right) - \prod_{\substack{1\leq k\leq n\\\gcd(k,n) = 1}}(x-k)
\]are divisible by $n$.
problems.solution:
We can actually classify all $n$ with the requested property.



An integer $n$ satisfies the property if and only if it is prime, 4, or twice a Fermat prime. (Hence answer 19.) It's obvious that primes work; to see that $n = 2p$ works if $p$ is a Fermat prime, note that

\[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k,n) = 1}}(x-k) \equiv (x - 1)^{p-1} \equiv x^{p-1} - 1 \pmod{2}\]since $p-1$ is a power of 2, and also

\[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k,n) = 1}}(x-k) \equiv \prod_{1 \le k \le p-1} (x-k) \equiv x^{p-1} - 1 \pmod{p}\]as expected. The case $n = 4$ can be checked directly.

Now we show these $n$ are all. Suppose $n$ satisfies the condition.



Lemma. (Necessary condition modulo $p$) Let $p$ be a prime divisor of $n$. Then $\varphi(n)$ equals $p-1$ times a power of $p$.



Proof. Suppose $p$ prime divides $n$. Then modulo $p$,

\[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k,n) = 1}}(x-k) \equiv \prod_{1 \le k \le p-1} (x-k)^{\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p-1}} \equiv (x^{p-1} - 1)^{\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p-1}}\]which is supposed to equal $x^{\varphi(n)} - 1$. This only happens when $\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p-1}$ is a power of $p$, which concludes the proof.

Claim. (Elimination of non-prime powers) If $n$ is not a prime power, then $n$ is twice a Fermat prime.



Proof. Suppose $p > q$ are two distinct primes dividing $n$. Then $(p-1)(q-1) \mid \varphi(n)$, so

$q-1$ is a power of $p$, and
$p-1$ is a power of $q$.

But $q-1 < p$, so $q-1 = 1$ and $q = 2$. Thus $p = 2^s + 1$ for some $s$.



This also demonstrates that 2 and $2^s + 1$ are the only prime factors of $n$, so let $n = 2^e (2^s + 1)^f$. Then $\varphi(n) = 2^{e+s-1} (2^s + 1)^{f-1}$. This is supposed to be a power of 2, so $f = 1$. It is also supposed to be $2^s$ times a power of $2^s + 1$, so $e+s-1 = s$, whence $e = 1$. Hence $n = 2(2^s + 1)$ as expected.

Now only prime power $n$ remain to be dealt with. Write $n = p^e$, say, with $e \ge 2$ (since we know $e = 1$ works). Then we require

\[x^{p^{e-1}(p-1)} - 1 \equiv \prod_{\substack{1 \le k \le p^e\\p \nmid k}} (x-k) \pmod{n}\]or, upon setting $x \mapsto x-1$,

\[(x-1)^{p^{e-1}(p-1)} - 1 \equiv \prod_{\substack{1 \le k \le p^e\\p \nmid k-1}} (x-k) \pmod{n}.\]It is clear that $x^2$ does not divide the LHS above. However, if $e \neq 2$, then the RHS contains the three distinct factors $x$, $x-p$, $x-p^{e-1}$, which collectively contain a factor of $x^2$ (as $x$ divides $(x-p)(x-p^{e-1})$).



Thus $e = 2$. Likewise, if $p \neq 2$, the RHS contains the three distinct factors $x$, $x-p$, $x-2p$, which multiply to a product divisible by $x^2$, contradiction.



Thus $(p, e) = (2, 2)$, so $n = 2^2 = 4$, as expected.

problems.title: 2019 C/CS1: Multiple of Four
problems.text: Patrick tosses four four-sided dice, each numbered $1$ through $4$. What's the probability their product is a multiple of four?
problems.solution:
Using complementary counting, the chance that the cube does not have a 4 is $1-\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^4=\left(\frac{175}{256}\right).$



Then, we have cases for the four die of they are 1 to 3:



$2, 2, 2, 2: 1$ way

$2, 2, 2, (1, 3): 4 \times 2=8$ ways

$2, 2, (1, 3), (1, 3): 6 \times 4 = 24$ ways



adding them up, there is $\frac{1+8+24+175}{256}=\frac{208}{256}=\boxed{\frac{13}{16}}.$

problems.title: 2019 C/CS2: Coloring the Vertices of a Cube
problems.text: How many ways are there to color the vertices of a cube red, blue, or green such that no edge connects two vertices of the same color? Rotations and reflections are considered distinct colorings.
problems.solution:
We don't need colors yet, so WLOG,  we can first name one vertex A.



The vertices around it must be BBB or BBC (since CCB and CCC are both the same, we use WLOG).



Case 1: BBB. By doing a mini-bash, you find that there are $10$ ways to color it.

Case 2: BBC. By doing a mini-bash, you find that there are $9$ ways to color it.



Adding up, we have $10+9=19$.



But wait! We haven't specified the colors for $A$, $B$, and $C$.



We have $3!=6$ ways to specify the colors of $A$, $B$ and $C$. Thus, the total number of colorings is $19 \times 6 = \boxed{114}$.

problems.title: 2019 C/CS3: Two Numbers Multiply to a Third
problems.text: How many ordered triples $(a,b,c)$ of integers with $1\le a\le b\le c\le 60$ satisfy $a\cdot b=c$?
problems.solution:
By speculating, we observe that $a \le 7$, because if $a\ge 8,$ then $b \ge 8$ too, so $c \ge 64$.



We count the number of cases for $a=1, 2, ..., 7$.



$a=1: 60$ ways.

$a=2: 29$ ways.

$a=3: 18$ ways.

$a=4: 12$ ways.

$a=5: 8$ ways.

$a=6: 5$ ways.

$a=7: 2$ ways.



Adding up, we get $60+29+18+12+8+5+2=\boxed{134}$.

problems.title: 2019 C/CS4: A Search Algorithm
problems.text:
Define a search algorithm called $\texttt{powSearch}$. Throughout, assume $A$ is a 1-indexed sorted array of distinct integers. To search for an integer $b$ in this array, we search the indices $2^0,2^1,\ldots$ until we either reach the end of the array or $A[2^k] > b$. If at any point we get $A[2^k] = b$ we stop and return $2^k$. Once we have $A[2^k] > b > A[2^{k-1}]$, we throw away the first $2^{k-1}$ elements of $A$, and recursively search in the same fashion. For example, for an integer which is at position $3$ we will search the locations $1, 2, 4, 3$.



Define $g(x)$ to be a function which returns how many (not necessarily distinct) indices we look at when calling $\texttt{powSearch}$ with an integer $b$ at position $x$ in $A$. For example, $g(3) = 4$. If $A$ has length $64$, find

\[g(1) + g(2) + \ldots + g(64).\]
problems.solution:
If we have $2^k$ numbers, then doubling the number of numbers would just be adding $k$ to all numbers and then subtracting $k-2$ from the last number for a duplicate. Let $f(2^k)$ be the sum of the $g$s from $1$ to $2^k$. Then, we have $f(2^{k+1})=2f(2^k)+(k+2) \times 2^k-(k+1)$.



By calculating the first few numbers, we have $f(4)=10$. Thus, $f(8)=33$, $f(16)=102$, $f(32)=295$ and $f(64) = \boxed{808}$.

problems.title: 2019 C/CS8: Algorithm on a Graph
problems.text:
Consider the following graph algorithm (where $V$ is the set of vertices and $E$ the set of edges in $G$).



$\textbf{procedure }\textsc{s}(G)$

$\qquad \textbf{if } |V| = 0\textbf{ then return true}$

$\qquad \textbf{for }(u,v)\textbf{ in }E\textbf{ do}$

$\qquad\qquad H\gets G-u-v$

$\qquad\qquad\textbf{if } \textsc{s}(H)\textbf{ then return true}$

$\qquad\textbf{return false}$



Here $G - u - v$ means the subgraph of $G$ which does not contain vertices $u,v$ and all edges using them. How many graphs $G$ with vertex set $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ and exactly $6$ edges satisfy $s(G)$ being true?

problems.title: 2019 C/CS10: Rooted Trees Equivalent Under Cycling
problems.text:
Define a rooted tree to be a tree $T$ with a singular node designated as the root of $T$.  (Note that every node in the tree can have an arbitrary number of children.)  Each vertex adjacent to the root node of $T$ is itself the root of some tree called a maximal subtree of $T$.



Say two rooted trees $T_1$ and $T_2$ are similar if there exists some way to cycle the maximal subtrees of $T_1$ to get $T_2$. For example, the first pair of trees below are similar but the second pair are not. How many rooted trees with $2019$ nodes are there up to similarity?

problems.title: 2019 G1: Intersection of Two Congruent Triangles
problems.text: The figure below depicts two congruent triangles with angle measures $40^\circ$, $50^\circ$, and $90^\circ$.  What is the measure of the obtuse angle $\alpha$ formed by the hypotenuses of these two triangles?
problems.solution:
Consider the quadrilateral formed by the union of the two triangles. Since three of the angles are clearly $90^{\circ}$, $50^{\circ}$, and $50^{\circ}$, the final angle is simply

$$360^{\circ}-(50^{\circ}+50^{\circ}+90^{\circ})=\boxed{170^{\circ}}.$$

problems.title: 2019 G2: Minimum Distance Between Circumcenters
problems.text: Suppose $X, Y, Z$ are collinear points in that order such that $XY = 1$ and $YZ = 3$. Let $W$ be a point such that $YW = 5$, and define $O_1$ and $O_2$ as the circumcenters of triangles $\triangle WXY$ and $\triangle WYZ$, respectively. What is the minimum possible length of segment $\overline{O_1O_2}$?
problems.solution: $\overline{WY}$ lies on the radical axis of the circumcircles. Furthermore, $H$ is the midpoint of $\overline{WY}.$ Angle chase to find $\angle{X} = \angle{YO_1H}, \angle{Z} = \angle{YO_2H}$ so $\triangle{YO_1O_2} \sim \triangle{WXZ}.$ Thus, $\frac{O_1O_2}{HY} = \frac{XZ}{h_W} \iff O_1O_2 = \frac{4 \cdot \frac{5}{2}}{h_W} = \frac{10}{h_W}.$ Since $WY = 5,$ the maximum value of $h_W$ is $5,$ when $\overline{WY} \perp \overline{XZ};$ any other configuration gives less. Thus, $O_1O_2 \geq \boxed{2}.$

problems.title: 2019 G3: Isosceles Right Triangle in an Equilateral Triangle
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be an equilateral triangle with side length $2$, and let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$.  Points $X$ and $Y$ are placed on $AB$ and $AC$ respectively such that $\triangle XMY$ is an isosceles right triangle with a right angle at $M$.  What is the length of $\overline{XY}$?
problems.solution: The problem is symmetric, so $\angle{BMX} = \angle{CMY} = 45 \iff \angle{BXM} = \angle{CYM} = 75.$ Using Law of Sines on $\triangle{BXM}$, we see that $\frac{XM}{\sin 60} = \frac{1}{\sin 75} \iff XY = XM \sqrt{2} = \frac{ \sqrt{2} \sin 60}{\sin 75} = \boxed{3 - \sqrt{3}}.$

problems.title: 2019 G4: Cube in a Right Tetrahedron
problems.text: Suppose $\mathcal{T}=A_0A_1A_2A_3$ is a  tetrahedron with $\angle A_1A_0A_3 = \angle A_2A_0A_1 = \angle A_3A_0A_2 = 90^\circ$, $A_0A_1=5, A_0A_2=12$ and $A_0A_3=9$. A cube $A_0B_0C_0D_0E_0F_0G_0H_0$ with side length $s$ is inscribed inside $\mathcal{T}$ with $B_0\in \overline{A_0A_1}, D_0 \in \overline{A_0A_2}, E_0 \in \overline{A_0A_3}$, and $G_0\in \triangle A_1A_2A_3$; what is $s$?
problems.solution: Using 3D coordinates, let $A_0=(0,0,0)$, $A_1=(5,0,0)$, $A_2=(0,12,0)$, and $A_3=(0,0,9)$. The point $G_0$ has coordinates $(s,s,s)$ such that it is on the plane defined by $A_0$, $A_1$, $A_2$. One equation for this plane is $1=\frac{1}{5}x+\frac{1}{12}y+\frac{1}{9}z$, and setting $x=y=z=s$, we get $1=\frac{71}{180}s$, so $s=\boxed{\frac{180}{71}}$.

problems.title: 2019 G5: MATH MASH
problems.text: Let $MATH$ be a trapezoid with $MA=AT=TH=5$ and $MH=11$.  Point $S$ is the orthocenter of $\triangle ATH$.  Compute the area of quadrilateral $MASH$.
problems.solution: Let $P$ be the foot from $A$ to $\overline{MH},$ and $P'$ (not drawn) the foot from $T$ to $\overline{MH}.$ Since $MATH$ is symmetrical, we have $MP = HP'$ and $MP + PP' + HP' = MP + HP' + 5 = MH = 11 \iff MP + HP' = 6 \iff MP = 3,$ so $AP = 4.$ Furthermore, let $\overline{SR}, \overline{AQ}$ be the $T-$ and $A-$ altitudes of $\triangle{HAT},$ respectively. We clearly see that $\triangle{SQT} \sim \triangle{ART} \iff SQ = \frac{AR \cdot QT}{RT}.$ However, by Pythagorean Theorem we have $AH = \sqrt{4^2 + 8^2} = 4\sqrt{5},$ so $AR = 2\sqrt{5}$ and $TR = \sqrt{5};$ by common sense $QT = 3$ and $QH = 4$ so $SQ = 6$ and $SH = 10.$ Thus, $[MASH] = [PAM] + [PASH] = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 3 \cdot 4 + \frac{1}{2} (4 + 10) \cdot 8 = 6 + 56 = \boxed{62}.$

problems.title: 2019 G6: Parallel to Side of Triangle Through Arc Midpoint
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=209$, $AC=243$, and $\angle BAC = 60^\circ$, and denote by $N$ the midpoint of the major arc $\widehat{BAC}$ of circle $\odot(ABC)$.  Suppose the parallel to $AB$ through $N$ intersects $\overline{BC}$ at a point $X$.  Compute the ratio $\tfrac{BX}{XC}$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10TrigLet $\angle{ABN} = a$ and note that $N \in \overarc{AC}.$ Since $N$ is the midpoint of $\overarc{BAC}$ we have $BN = CN,$ but since $\angle{BNC} = \angle{BAC} = 60$ we see that $\triangle{BCN}$ is equilateral. Since $\overline{AB} \parallel \overline{XN}$ we have $\angle{BNX} = a$ as well. Use Law of Sines on $\triangle{BXN}$ and $\triangle{CXN}$ to get $$\dfrac{BX}{\sin{a}} = \dfrac{NX}{\sin{60}}; \dfrac{CX}{\sin{60 - a}} = \dfrac{NX}{\sin{60}}.$$Combine the two to get $$\dfrac{BX}{CX} = \dfrac{\sin{a}}{\sin{60 - a}} = \dfrac{\sin a}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos a - \frac{1}{2} \sin a} = \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{3} \cot a - 1}.$$Now, $\angle{ABN}$ and $\angle{ACN}$ subtend the same arc, so they are equal; thus $\angle{B} = a + 60, \angle{C} = 60 - a.$ Use the Law of Sines on $\triangle{ABC}$ and get $$\dfrac{209}{\sin (60 - a)} = \dfrac{243}{\sin (a + 60)}.$$Now, solve for $\cot a.$

\begin{align*}
209\left(\frac{1}{2} \sin a + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos a\right) &= 243 \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos a - \frac{1}{2} \sin a\right) \\
209 \sin a + 209 \sqrt{3} \cos a &= 243 \sqrt{3} \cos a - 243 \sin a \\
34 \sqrt{3} \cos a &= 452 \sin a \\
\cot a &= \dfrac{226}{17 \sqrt{3}}
\end{align*}Substitute back in and solve, getting $$\dfrac{BX}{CX} = \dfrac{2}{\frac{226}{17} - 1} = \boxed{\dfrac{34}{209}}.$$

problems.title: 2019 G8: Three Reflections
problems.text:
Consider the following three lines in the Cartesian plane: $$\begin{cases}
\ell_1: & 2x - y = 7\\
\ell_2: & 5x + y = 42\\
\ell_3: & x + y = 14
\end{cases}$$and let $f_i(P)$ correspond to the reflection of the point $P$ across $\ell_i$. Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are points on the $x$ and $y$ axes, respectively, such that $f_1(f_2(f_3(X)))= Y$. Let $t$ be the length of segment $XY$; what is the sum of all possible values of $t^2$?
problems.solution: First note that all three lines pass through $(7,7)$. Let $\theta_{1}$, $\theta_{2}$, $\theta_{3}$ be the angle that the three lines form with the ray with endpoint $(7,7)$ in the positive $x$ direction. It's not hard to see that $\theta_{1} = \arctan{2}$, $\theta_{2}=\arctan{-5}$, and $\theta_{3}=\arctan{-1}$. Note that if a point $P$ makes an angle $\theta$ with the ray defined above, then $f_{3}(P)$ will be the same distance from $(7,7)$ as $P$ and will form an angle of $2\theta_{3}-\theta$ with the ray. Repeating this process, we get that $f_1(f_2(f_3(P)))$ will form an angle of $2\theta_{1}-(2\theta_{2}-(2\theta_{3}-\theta))$ with the ray, which is equivalent to reflecting $P$ across a line passing through $(7,7)$ forming an angle of $\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}+\theta_{3}$ with the ray. This line has slope $\tan(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}+\theta_{3})$, which can be computed to be $-8$. Thus, we want to find points on the $x$-axis such that when reflected over $y=-8x+63$. From here, it can be seen that there is only one such point, namely, $X=(16,0)$, which maps to $Y=(0,-2)$. $XY^2=2^2+16^2=\boxed{260}$.

problems.title: 2019 G9: Locus of Circumcenters of Right Triangles
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a square of side length $1$, and let $P_1, P_2$ and $P_3$ be points on the perimeter such that $\angle P_1P_2P_3 = 90^\circ$ and $P_1, P_2, P_3$ lie on different sides of the square. As these points vary, the locus of the circumcenter of $\triangle P_1P_2P_3$ is a region $\mathcal{R}$; what is the area of $\mathcal{R}$?
problems.solution:
Consider the figure formed by the eight parabolas with a focus at one of the vertices of the square and a directrix at each of the two sides opposite to its focus. I claim that this figure is indeed the desired locus.



Firstly, assume that $P_1$ and $P_3$ lie on adjacent vertices since otherwise, the locus will simply be one of the midlines of the square which is clearly contained within the claimed locus. Then WLOG, assume that $P_1 \in AB$, $P_2 \in BC$, and $P_3 \in AD$. For any $P_1P_3$ to be the hypotenuse of a right triangle, there must exist a $P_2 \in BC$ such that $\angle P_1P_2P_3=90^\circ$, or equivalently, the circle $\omega$ with diameter $P_1P_3$ must intersect side $BC$. Note that $A \in \omega$ so $\omega$ intersects $BC$ iff, $d(M,BC) \le AM$ where $M$ is the midpoint of $P_1P_3$ since $\overline{AM}$ is a radius of $\omega$. Also $M$ must lie in the upper right quadrant of the square since otherwise $\omega$ will intersect $BC$ outside of the segment so the desired locus for this particular configuration is the region of points in the upper right quadrant of the square lying to the left of the parabola with focus $A$ and directrix $BC$. Applying the same argument for the other possibilities yields the desired locus.



Now we compute the area. Scale the square so that its center lies at the origin and $A=(1,1)$. Then the intersection of the parabolas in the upper right quadrant is the intersection of $y=\tfrac{1}{4}(x-1)^2$ and $y=x$, or $(3-2\sqrt{2},3-2\sqrt{2})$. Then the area of the locus is

\[ 4 \cdot (3-2\sqrt{2})^2+8\int_{3-2\sqrt{2}}^1 \tfrac{1}{4}(x-1)^2 dx=\tfrac{1}{3}(92-64\sqrt{2})\]so after scaling back to a unit square, we arrive at the answer $\boxed{\tfrac{1}{3}(23-16\sqrt{2})}$.

problems.title: 2019 G10: Erecting Right Triangles Outside of Another Triangle
problems.text: Suppose $ABC$ is a triangle, and define $B_1$ and $C_1$ such that $\triangle AB_1C$ and $\triangle AC_1B$ are isosceles right triangles on the exterior of $\triangle ABC$ with right angles at $B_1$ and $C_1$, respectively. Let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{B_1C_1}$; if $B_1C_1 = 12$, $BM = 7$ and $CM = 11$, what is the area of $\triangle ABC$?
problems.solution:
Let $X$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$, and let $A_1$ be the point such that $\triangle BA_1C$ is right isosceles with right angle at $A_1$, pointing towards $\triangle ABC$. We prove two claims, the first of which is well-known.



Lemma. Quadrilateral $AB_1A_1C_1$ is a parallelogram.

Proof. Let $U$ and $V$ be the midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ (not in diagram). Since $\triangle B_1AC \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle C_1BA$, by mean geometry the midpoint triangle $\triangle MUV$ is similar to both, and directly similar to $\triangle A_1BC$. Thus $M$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AA_1}$ too, done.



Lemma. (Main claim) The triangle $XB_1C_1$ is right isosceles with right angle at $X$.

Proof. Let $Y$ be the reflection of $C$ over $B_1$; define $Z$ similarly. Note $\triangle A_1BC \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle CAY$, so the midpoint triangle $\triangle MXB_1 \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle A_1BC$. Likewise $\triangle MC_1X \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle A_1BC$, so $\triangle XB_1C_1$ is right isosceles at $X$, as desired.



With these two claims, the remainder of the solution is easy. Since $B_1C_1 = 12$, $MX = 6$. Now

\[BC^2 = 2\big(MB^2 + MC^2\big) - 4MX^2 = 2(7^2 + 11^2) - 12^2 = 196\]and so $BC = 14$. By Heron's formula, the area of $\triangle MBC$ equals $\sqrt{16 \cdot 9 \cdot 5 \cdot 2} = 12\sqrt{10}$. Finally, since $M$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AA_1}$,

\[[ABC] = 2[MBC] - [A_1BC] = 2 \cdot 12\sqrt{10} - \big(\tfrac{14}{2}\big)^2 = 24\sqrt{10} - 49.\]

problems.title: 2019 T2: Ordered Pairs Satisfying GCD Property
problems.text:
Determine the number of ordered pairs of positive integers $(m,n)$ with $1\leq m\leq 100$ and $1\leq n\leq 100$ such that

\[
    \gcd(m+1,n+1) = 10\gcd(m,n).
    \]
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247solIn the set $S=\{9,19,29,39,49,59,69,79,89,99\}$ the only pairs that are not relatively prime are $(9,39)$, $(9,69)$, $(9,99)$, $(39,69)$, $(39, 99)$ $(69,99)$. It can be checked that none of these pairs satisfy the condition. On the other hand, note that if $a,b$ are relatively prime elements of $S$ and $\gcd(a+1,b+1)=10$, then the condition will be satisfied. Furthermore, the $5$ pairs $(9,39)$, $(9,69)$, $(9,99)$, $(39,69)$ satisfy the property that $\gcd(a+1,b+1)=10$. Finally, note that $\gcd(a,b)=10$ if $a,b$ are multiples of $10$ and $\gcd(a/10,b/10)=1$. In the end, all this implies that the answer is $$2\left(\sum_{k=2}^{10} \varphi(k)-5\right)=\boxed{52}$$where $\varphi(k)$ is the Euler totient function.

problems.title: 2019 T10: Areas of Triangles Formed by Excircle Tangency Points
problems.text: Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with side lengths $a$, $b$, and $c$.  Circle $\omega_A$ is the $A$-excircle of $\triangle ABC$, defined as the circle tangent to $BC$ and to the extensions of $AB$ and $AC$ past $B$ and $C$ respectively.  Let $\mathcal{T}_A$ denote the triangle whose vertices are these three tangency points; denote $\mathcal{T}_B$ and $\mathcal{T}_C$ similarly. \[[\mathcal{T}_A]=[XYZ]=[XYI_A]+[YZI_A]-[XZI_A]=\frac{r_A^2}{2}\left(\sin B+\sin C-\sin A\right)=\frac{r_A^2}{2R}(s-a)=\frac{K^2}{2R(s-a)}.\]Now $[\mathcal{T}_A]:[\mathcal{T}_B]:[\mathcal{T}_C]=4:5:6$ gives $(s-a)=\tfrac{x}{4},(s-b)=\tfrac{x}{5},(s-c)=\tfrac{x}{6},$ from which it is not hard to extract the answer $22:25:27.$

problems.title: 2019 T11: Subset of Natural Numbers Satisfying Inclusion Property
problems.text: Let $S$ be a subset of the natural numbers such that $0\in S$, and for all $n\in\mathbb N$, if $n$ is in $S$, then both $2n+1$ and $3n+2$ are in $S$.  What is the smallest number of elements $S$ can have in the range $\{0,1,\ldots, 2019\}$?
problems.solution:
Y by Einstein314, Adventure10, Mango247

Quote:
Let $S$ be a subset of the natural numbers such that $0\in S$

disgusting



The main observation is that if $f(n)=2n+1$ and $g(n)=3n+2,$ $f(g(n))=g(f(n)).$ Thus all that matters is how many times we apply each of $f$ and $g.$ Now let $h(a,b)=g^b(f^a(0)).$ We claim that $h$ is injective; assume $h(a_1,b_1)=h(a_2,b_2).$ Note that the base $3$ representation of $h(a,b)$ ends with exactly $2$ $3$s, as $f^a(0)$ cannot end with a $2.$ Thus  $b_1=b_2$ whence $a_1=a_2$ follows.



Now we count by casework on $a.$



\[0\to 2\to 8\to 26\to 80\to 242\to 728\]\[1\to 4\to 14\to 44\to 134\to 404\to 1214\]\[3\to 11\to 35\to 107\to 323\to 971\]\[7\to 23\to 71\to 215\to 647\to 1943\]\[15\to 47\to 143\to 431\to 1295\]\[31\to 95\to 287\to 863\]\[63\to 191\to 575\to 1727\]\[127\to 383\to 1151\]\[255\to 767\]\[511\to 1535\]\[1023\]so the answer is $47$ or smth

problems.title: 2019 T13: A Peculiar Laser
problems.text: Points $A$, $B$, and $C$ lie in the plane such that $AB=13$, $BC=14$, and $CA=15$.  A peculiar laser is fired from $A$ perpendicular to $\overline{BC}$.  After bouncing off $BC$, it travels in a direction perpendicular to $CA$.  When it hits $CA$, it travels in a direction perpendicular to $AB$, and after hitting $AB$ its new direction is perpendicular to $BC$ again.  If this process is continued indefinitely, the laser path will eventually approach some finite polygonal shape $T_\infty$.  What is the ratio of the perimeter of $T_\infty$ to the perimeter of $\triangle ABC$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10The limit case will be $\triangle XYZ$ with $X\in\overline{BC},Y\in\overline{CA},Z\in\overline{AB}$ with $XY\perp AC,YZ\perp BA,ZX\perp CB.$ Angle chasing shows $\triangle YZX\sim \triangle ABC.$ We now coordinate bash.



Let $B=(-5,0),C=(9,0),A=(0,12),X=(a,0).$ We quickly compute $Y=\left(a,\frac{60a+300}{25}\right),Z=\left(\frac{9a+144}{25},\frac{-12a+108}{25}\right),$ so since $YZ$ has slope $\tfrac{-5}{12},$

\[\frac{72a+192}{16a-144}=\frac{9a+24}{2a-18}=\frac{-5}{12}\implies a=\frac{-99}{59}.\]Then $BX=\tfrac{196}{59}\implies XZ=\tfrac{2352}{295},$ from which we extract the answer $\tfrac{168}{295}.$

problems.title: 2019 T15: Prime-Covering Polynomials
problems.text: Call a polynomial $P$ prime-covering if for every prime $p$, there exists an integer $n$ for which $p$ divides $P(n)$. Determine the number of ordered triples of integers $(a,b,c)$, with $1\leq a < b < c \leq 25$, for which $P(x)=(x^2-a)(x^2-b)(x^2-c)$ is prime-covering.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10If one of $a,b,c$ are squares, the corresponding factor splits into linear factors, at which point it is clear that $P$ is prime-covering. There are $\tbinom{25}{3}-\tbinom{20}{3}$ such cases; now assume there are no squares.



Note that every number $\leq 25$ has at most two distinct prime divisors. Thus we write $a=p^uq^v.$ Then we want to characterize the primes $r$ in which $p^uq^v$ is a QR. Since we dispensed of the square case, there are only two more cases:



Case 1: $u\equiv 1\mod 2, v\equiv 0\mod 2.$

Then this is equivalent to $p$ being a QR. Call this $a$ type 1.

Case 2: $u\equiv 1\mod 2,v\equiv 1\mod 2.$

In this case, both $p$ and $q$ are either QRs or NQRs. Call this $a$ type 2.



Now consider the case that one of $a,b,c$ is type 1; WLOG it is $a$ with relevant prime factor $p.$ Then to account for the $p$ NQR case, we need one of $b,c$ to be type 2 with prime $p$ and some other prime $q.$ Then to account for the $q$ QR case, we need the other one of $b,c$ to be type $1$ with relevant prime factor $q$ (it can't be type $2$ with some third prime because that creates counterexamples with Dirichlet).



With similar case analysis, the only case where all of $a,b,c$ are type $2$ is when the relevant primes of $a,b,c$ are $\{p,q\},\{q,r\},\{r,p\}.$



We now compute the answer for each case. We first separate the remaining numbers by type:

\[1: 2,3,5,7,8,11,12,13,17,18,19,20,23\]\[2: 6,10,14,15,21,22,24\]For the first case, we do casework on the two primes. $p=2$ yields three cases for the type $1,$ $p=3,5$ yields two cases for the type $1,$ $(p,q)=(2,3)$ yields two cases for the type $2,$ and everything else has one case. Adding everything gives $30$ cases.



For the second case, the primes must be $(2,3,5)$ or $(2,3,7).$ This adds another $4$ cases.

We conclude that there are $\tbinom{25}{3}-\tbinom{20}{3}+34=1194$ prime-covering polynomials.



EDIT: Thanks @below, I forgot a lot of cases where primes have multiplicity $\geq 2.$ Note that the characterization above matches dj's characterization in post #3.

problems.title: 2018 CS5: Memory access
problems.text: An $\textit{access pattern}$ $\pi$ is a permutation of $\{1,2,\dots,50\}$ describing the order in which some $50$ memory addresses are accessed. We define the $\textit{locality}$ of $\pi$ to be how much the program jumps around the memory, or numerically, \[\sum_{i=2}^{50}\left\lvert\pi(i)-\pi(i-1)\right\rvert.\]If $\pi$ is a uniformly randomly chosen access pattern, what is the expected value of its locality?
problems.solution: Given two randomly chosen distinct numbers from $\{1, 2, \ldots, 50\},$ since there are $48$ other numbers, it follows that there are expected to be $\tfrac{48}{3}=16$ numbers in between those two chosen numbers. Therefore, the expected size of the jump that the program has to do to get from one of the numbers to the other is $16+1=17,$ so, by Linearity of Expectation, the answer is $$17 \cdot 49 = \boxed{833}.$$$\square$

problems.text: For integer $n\geq 2$ and real $0\leq p\leq 1$, define $\mathcal{W}_{n,p}$ to be the complete weighted undirected random graph with vertex set $\{1,2,\ldots,n\}$: the edge $(i,j)$ will have weight $\min(i,j)$ with probability $p$ and weight $\max(i,j)$ otherwise. Let $\mathcal{L}_{n,p}$ denote the total weight of the minimum spanning tree of $\mathcal{W}_{n,p}$. Find the largest integer less than the expected value of $\mathcal{L}_{2018,1/2}$.

problems.title: 2018 CS7: Randomized Expected Value
problems.text: I give you a function $\textbf{rand}$ that returns a number chosen uniformly at random from $[0,T]$ for some number $T$ that you don't know. Your task is to approximate $T$. You do this by calling $\textbf{rand}$ $100$ times, recording the results as $X_1,X_2,\dots,X_{100}$, and guessing \[\hat{T}=\alpha\cdot\max\{X_1,X_2,\dots,X_{100}\}\]for some $\alpha$. Which value of $\alpha$ ensures that $\mathbb{E}[\hat{T}]=T$?

problems.title: 2018 CS8: Balanced Parentheses
problems.text:
We consider a simple model for balanced parenthesis checking. Let $\mathcal R=\{\texttt{(())}\rightarrow \texttt{A},\texttt{(A)}\rightarrow\texttt{A},\texttt{AA}\rightarrow\texttt{A}\}$ be a set of rules for phrase reduction. Ideally, any given phrase is balanced if and only if the model is able to reduce the phrase to $\texttt{A}$ by some arbitrary sequence of rule applications. For example, to show $\texttt{((()))}$ is balanced we can perform the following sequence of reductions.

\[\texttt{((()))}\rightarrow\texttt{(A)}\rightarrow\texttt{A}\qquad \checkmark\]Unfortunately, the above set of rules $\mathcal R$ is not complete, since there exist parenthetical phrases which are balanced but which are not balanced according to $\mathcal R$.  Determine the number of such phrases of length $14$.
problems.solution:
Let $f(n)$ denote the number of correctly detected balanced phrases of length $2n$. Then we recursively find $f(n)$ by case work on where the ) corresponding to the first ) appears. For example for n=4:



( _ _ _ _ _ _ ), $f(n-1)$ ways to fill in the blanks

( _ _ _ _ ) _ _ , $f(1) \cdot f(n-2)$ ways to fill in the blanks

( _ _ ) _ _ _ _, $f(2) \cdot f(n-3)$ ways to fill in the blanks



but we still need to consider the extra rule that (()) -> A which allows there to be a solution in ( _ _ ) _ _ _ _ by filling in ( ( ) ) _ _ _ _ even though $f(n-3)=f(1)=0$.



Continuing for arbitrary $n$, we have $f(n) = f(n-1) +f(n-2)+ \sum_{i=1}^{n-3} f(i) \cdot f(n-i-1) $ which gives us $f(n)=\{0,1,1,2,4,8,17\}$ for $n=1,2,3,4,5,6,7$ so the answer is $\tfrac{1}{8} \tbinom{14}{7}-17 = \boxed{412}$.

problems.title: 2018 CS9: Weighted Binary Search
problems.text:
Consider the following modified algorithm for binary search, which we will call $\textit{weighted binary search}$:



\begin{tabular}{l}
01: \textbf{FUNCTION} SEARCH($L$, value) \\
02:$\qquad$  hi $\leftarrow$ $\operatorname{len}(L) - 1$ \\
03:$\qquad$  lo $\leftarrow$ 0 \\
04:$\qquad$  \textbf{WHILE} hi $\geq$ lo \\
05:$\qquad\qquad$ guess $\leftarrow$ $\lfloor w \cdot\text{lo} + (1-w) \cdot \text{hi}\rfloor$ \\
06:$\qquad\qquad$ mid $\leftarrow$ $L[\text{guess}]$ \\
07:$\qquad\qquad$ \textbf{IF} mid $> \text{value}$ \\
08: $\qquad\qquad\qquad$ hi $\leftarrow$ $\text{guess} - 1$ \\
09: $\qquad\qquad$ \textbf{ELSE IF} mid $< \text{value}$ \\
10: $\qquad\qquad\qquad$ lo $\leftarrow$ $\text{guess} + 1$ \\
11: $\qquad\qquad$ \textbf{ELSE} \\
12: $\qquad\qquad\qquad$ \textbf{RETURN} guess \\
13:$\qquad$ \textbf{RETURN} -1 (not found) 
\end{tabular}



Assume $L$ is a list of the integers $\{1,2,\ldots,100\}$, in that order. Further assume that accessing the $k$th index of $L$ costs $k+1$ tokens (e.g. $L[0]$ costs $1$ token). Let $S$ be the set of all $w\in[\tfrac12,1)$ which minimize the average cost when $\texttt{value}$ is an integer selected at random in the range $[1,50]$. Given that $S=\left(x,\tfrac {74}{99}\right]$, determine $x$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10Extension to this problem: prove $\max S=\frac {74}{99}$. I do not know how to rigorously do this as of yet.



Far future: Further generalize to general $L=\{1,\ldots,2n\}$, selecting from $\{1,\ldots,n\}$ and provide a closed form for $\sup S$ and $\inf S$.

problems.title: 2018 CS10: Ants know algorithms
problems.text: Consider an undirected, connected graph $G$ with vertex set $\{v_1,v_2,\ldots, v_6\}$.  Starting at the vertex $v_1$, an ant uses a DFS algorithm to traverse through $G$ under the condition that if there are multiple unvisited neighbors of some vertex, the ant chooses the $v_i$ with smallest $i$.  How many possible graphs $G$ are there satisfying the following property: for each $1\leq i\leq 6$, the vertex $v_i$ is the $i^{\text{th}}$ new vertex the ant traverses?
problems.solution:
To solve this problem, it is first important to recall what depth-first search (DFS) is.  In a DFS algorithm, the ant will traverse through the vertices of a graph one at a time, travelling as far as possible before backtracking.  This is done subject to the condition that the ant finishes searching a vertex if and only if all of that vertex's neighbors are already visited.  The following example, taken from the 15-210 Parallel and Sequential Algorithms course textbook, might serve as a good visual aid (although here the DFS is being done on an ordered graph as opposed to an unordered one).  Here, $X$ denotes the set of visited vertices ordered from left to right.






Note that the bolded part of the graph indicating the exact edges traversed in the DFS search forms a tree; this makes sense, since such an algorithm never visits a vertex twice (which in turn would create a cycle).  The key to solving this problem is to focus on this underlying tree (called a DFS tree) and use this to develop a recursion that will help enumerate the number of graphs in question.



Consider any graph $G$ on $n+1$ vertices $\{v_1,\ldots, v_{n+1}\}$ satisfying the property in the question.  Delete the vertex $v_{n+1}$ and all edges incident on it.  Then the resulting graph $G'$ on $n$ vertices $\{v_1,\ldots, v_n\}$ also satisfies the property in question, since the DFS traversal for $G$ must go through the vertices $v_1,\ldots, v_n$ first before finally reaching $v_{n+1}$.  Now let $P$ denote the unique path connecting vertex $v_1$ to vertex $v_n$ in the DFS tree for $G'$.  The crucial claim is that all of the neighbors of $v_{n+1}$ must be entirely contained in $P$.  Indeed, if this were not the case, then $\{v_j,v_{n+1}\}\in E(G)$ for some $v_j\notin P$.  Note that by the property in the problem statement, in the DFS tree for $G'$, $v_j$ is traversed before $v_n$.  But now this means that in the DFS tree for $G$, vertex $v_{n+1}$ is traversed before $v_n$, since by definition the ant must visit all neighbors of $v_j$ before backtracking onto $P$.  This is a contradiction, and so indeed all neighbors of $v_{n+1}$ must be located on the path $P$.  In turn, one can construct a graph on $n+1$ vertices by first picking a vertex $v$ in $P$ for the ant to travel to $v_{n+1}$ and then selecting any subset of the vertices in the path from $v_1$ to $v$ not containing $v$ in the DFS tree to add as extra neighbors to $v_{n+1}$.  (These will not affect the correctness of the DFS tree due to the given ordering of the vertices, since the vertex $v_{n+1}$ will still be traversed last.)  The picture below demonstrates this. Here the DFS tree is represented in bold; the remaining dashed edges are optional and lead to the $2^k$ term in the recurrence.







The second important step is to recongize that the number of choices for where to place the branching-off point is dependent on the length of $P$.  Thus, for all positive integer pairs $(n,k)$ with $1\leq k\leq n-1$, let $G_{n,k}$ denote the number of connected graphs on $\{v_1,\ldots, v_n\}$ satisfying the following two properties:

The DFS search starting from vertex $v_1$ traverses $v_1,v_2,\ldots, v_n$ in this order;
In the DFS tree for the graph, the distance between vertices $v_1$ and $v_n$ is $k$.

Additionally, define $G_{n,0} = 0$ for convenience purposes.  Then in order to construct a graph counted in $G_{n+1,k+1}$, the vertex $v_{n+1}$ must be attached to the vertex in the path from $v_1$ to $v_n$ which is distance $k$ away from $v_1$; this can only be done if the length of the path is at least $k$.  Thus, by combining this with the logic above, one establishes the recursion \[G_{n+1,k+1} = 2^k\sum_{j=k}^nG_{n,j}.\]From here, it suffices to compute the $G_{n,k}$ manually.  The computation is a bit intensive when performing the calculations for the $n=6$ case, but it is still doable.

\[
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
$G_{n,k}$ & 0 & 1   & 2   & 3   & 4   & 5    \\ \hline
1         & 0 &     &     &     &     &      \\ \hline
2         & 0 & 1   &     &     &     &      \\ \hline
3         & 0 & 1   & 2   &     &     &      \\ \hline
4         & 0 & 3   & 6   & 8   &     &      \\ \hline
5         & 0 & 17  & 34  & 56  & 64  &      \\ \hline
6         & 0 & 171 & 342 & 616 & 960 & 1024 \\ \hline
\end{tabular}\]The requested answer is the sum of the entries along the bottom row, which is $\boxed{3113}$.



Remark: The sequence of answers for various $n$ - 1, 1, 3, 17, 171, 3113, 106419, ... - is sequence A015083 in the OEIS.  No closed form is known, but it is known that the generating function $A(x)$ for this recurrence satisfies the equation \[A(x) = \frac{1}{1-xA(2x)}.\]In this way, the sequence can be interpreted as a generalization of the Catalan number recurrence.

problems.title: 2018 Team 1-1/1-2: Circles
problems.text:
Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $BC=30$, $AC=50$, and $AB=60$.  Circle $\omega_B$ is the circle passing through $A$ and $B$ tangent to $BC$ at $B$; $\omega_C$ is defined similarly.  Suppose the tangent to $\odot(ABC)$ at $A$ intersects $\omega_B$ and $\omega_C$ for the second time at $X$ and $Y$ respectively.  Compute $XY$.



Let $T = TNYWR$. For some positive integer $k$, a circle is drawn tangent to the coordinate axes such that the lines $x + y = k^2, x + y = (k+1)^2, \dots, x+y = (k+T)^2$ all pass through it. What is the minimum possible value of $k$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango2471The tangencies imply $XAB \sim BCA $ and $YAC \sim CBA$. Then $XY=XA+AY=36+25=\boxed{61} $.



2Let the center of the circle be $(a,a) $. Then looking at the farthest lines and using distance from point to line we get $(k+61)^2 \le (2+\sqrt{2})a $ and $(2-\sqrt{2})a \le k^2$. Combining, we get $(2-\sqrt{2})(k+61)^2 \le (2+\sqrt{2})k^2$. This simplifies to $\frac{61}{k} \le \sqrt{2} $. Then the minimum $k $ is $\boxed{44} $.

problems.title: 2018 Team 2-1/2-2: Integer Equations
problems.text:
Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are non-negative integers satisfying $a + b + ab + a^b = 42$. Find the sum of all possible values of $a + b$.



Let $T = TNYWR$. Suppose that a sequence $\{a_n\}$ is defined via $a_1 = 11, a_2 = T$, and $a_n = a_{n-1} + 2a_{n-2}$ for $n \ge 3$. Find $a_{19} + a_{20}$.
problems.solution:
Firstly, trying the cases when $a$ or $b$ is $0$ or when $a$ or $b$ is $1,$ we get the solutions $(1,20), (0,42),$ and $(0,41).$ Otherwise, $a^b$ must be $4, 8, 9, 16, 25, 27, 32,$ or $36.$ Testing each of them yields the solutions $(3,3)$ and $(5,2).$



Therefore, the sum of all possible values of $a+b$ is

\begin{align*}
(1+20)+(0+42)+(0+41)+(3+3)+(5+2) &= 21+42+41+6+7 \\
&= \boxed{117}.
\end{align*}$\square$

problems.title: 2018 Team 3-1/3-2: Semicircle and Marbles
problems.text:
Let $\Omega$ be a semicircle with endpoints $A$ and $B$ and diameter 3. Points $X$ and $Y$ are located on the boundary of $\Omega$ such that the distance from $X$ to $AB$ is $\frac{5}{4}$ and the distance from $Y$ to $AB$ is $\frac{1}{4}$. Compute \[(AX+BX)^2 - (AY+BY)^2.\]

Let $T = TNYWR$. $T$ people each put a distinct marble into a bag; its contents are mixed randomly and one marble is distributed back to each person. Given that at least one person got their own marble back, what is the probability that everyone else also received their own marble?

problems.title: 2018 Team 4-1/4-2: Powers of Two and Rectangle
problems.text:
Define an integer $n \ge 0$ to be \textit{two-far} if there exist integers $a$ and $b$ such that $a$, $b$, and $n + a + b$ are all powers of two. If $N$ is the number of two-far integers less than 2048, find the remainder when $N$ is divided by 100.



Let $T = TNYWR$. Let $CMU$ be a triangle with $CM=13$, $MU=14$, and $UC=15$.  Rectangle $WEAN$ is inscribed in $\triangle CMU$ with points $W$ and $E$ on $\overline{MU}$, point $A$ on $\overline{CU}$, and point $N$ on $\overline{CM}$.  If the area of $WEAN$ is $T$, what is its perimeter?

problems.title: 2018 Team 5-1/5-2: Ordered Triples and Dice Rolling
problems.text:
How many ordered triples $(a,b,c)$ of integers satisfy the inequality \[a^2+b^2+c^2 \leq a+b+c+2?\]

Let $T = TNYWR$. David rolls a standard $T$-sided die repeatedly until he first rolls $T$, writing his rolls in order on a chalkboard. What is the probability that he is able to erase some of the numbers he's written such that all that's left on the board are the numbers $1, 2, \dots, T$ in order?
problems.solution:
Y by Williamgolly, Adventure101Complete the square and get $(2a-1)^2+(2b-1)^2+(2c-1)^2 \le 11$. Each term on the left is an odd square. The possible values are $(1,1,1) $ and permutations of $(9,1,1)$. This produces $\boxed{32}$ triples.



2For each $1,2,...,31$, there is a $\frac{1}{2}$ chance the number will appear before the $32$ is rolled. The answer is $\boxed{\frac{1}{2^{31}}} $.

problems.title: 2018 Team 6-1/6-2: Dice Rolling and Integer Sum

If the probability that the polynomial $\tfrac{x^2}{r} - x\sqrt{a} + b$ has a real root can be expressed as simplified fraction $\frac{p}{q}$, find $p$.



Let $T = TNYWR$. Compute the number of ordered triples $(a,b,c)$ such that $a$, $b$, and $c$ are distinct positive integers and $a + b + c = T$.

problems.title: 2018 Team 7-1/7-2: Unit Square and Road Trip
problems.text:
Let $ABCD$ be a unit square, and suppose that $E$ and $F$ are on $\overline{AD}$ and $\overline{AB}$ such that $AE = AF = \tfrac23$. Let $\overline{CE}$ and $\overline{DF}$ intersect at $G$. If the area of $\triangle CFG$ can be expressed as simplified fraction $\frac{p}{q}$, find $p + q$.



Let $T = TNYWR$. A total of $2T$ students go on a road trip. They take two cars, each of which seats $T$ people. Call two students \textit{friendly} if they sat together in the same car going to the trip and in the same car going back home. What is the smallest possible number of friendly pairs of students on the trip?

problems.title: 2018 Team 8-1/8-2: Triangle Cevians and Fourth Powers
problems.text:
Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=3$ and $AC=5$. Select points $D, E,$ and $F$ on $\overline{BC}$ in that order such that $\overline{AD}\perp \overline{BC}$, $\angle BAE=\angle CAE$, and $\overline{BF}=\overline{CF}$. If $E$ is the midpoint of segment $\overline{DF}$, what is $BC^2$?



Let $T = TNYWR$, and let $T = 10X + Y$ for an integer $X$ and a digit $Y$. Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are real numbers satisfying $a+\frac1b=Y$ and $\frac{b}a=X$. Compute $(ab)^4+\frac1{(ab)^4}$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure101We have $\frac{BD}{BC}+\frac{BF}{BC}=2\frac{BE}{BC}$. Substituting and simplifying, we find $\frac{BD}{CD}=\frac{1}{3}$. Using the pythagorean theorem we find $AD=\sqrt{7} \rightarrow BC^2=\boxed{32}$.



2Multiplying the two given equations, we find $\frac{1}{a}+b=6$. Multiplying this with $a+\frac{1}{b}=2$, we find $ab+\frac{1}{ab}=10$. Then $ab^2+\frac{1}{(ab)^2}=10^2-2=98$ and $ab^4+\frac{1}{(ab)^4}=98^2-2=\boxed{9602} $.

problems.title: 2018 Team 10-1/10-2: Tangent Circles & Integer Divisibility
problems.text:
Find the smallest positive integer $k$ such that $ \underbrace{11\cdots 11}_{k\text{ 1's}}$ is divisible by $9999$.



Let $T = TNYWR$. Circles $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ intersect at $P$ and $Q$.  The common external tangent $\ell$ to the two circles closer to $Q$ touches $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ at $A$ and $B$ respectively.  Line $AQ$ intersects $\omega_2$ at $X$ while $BQ$ intersects $\omega_1$ again at $Y$.  Let $M$ and $N$ denote the midpoints of $\overline{AY}$ and $\overline{BX}$, also respectively.  If $AQ=\sqrt{T}$, $BQ=7$, and $AB=8$, then find the length of $MN$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure101$1111$ and $9$ must divide the number. This implies $4 | k $ and $9 | k$, so $k=\boxed{36}$.



2From formula for length of median: $MN^2=\frac{2MX^2+2MB^2-BX^2}{4}=\frac{2\left( \frac{2XY^2+2XA^2-AY^2}{4} \right)+2\left( \frac{2YB^2+2AB^2-AY^2}{4} \right)-BX^2}{4}=\frac{XY^2+XA^2+YB^2+AB^2-AY^2-BX^2}{4}$.



We can find $XY^2$ from Law of Cosines. The other lengths can be calculated from the similar triangles $ABQ \sim YBA \sim AXB $. Then after a couple of calculations we find $MN=\boxed{\frac{128}{21}} $.

problems.title: 2018 G1: Difference of Angles
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle.  Point $P$ lies in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that $\angle ABP = 20^\circ$ and $\angle ACP = 15^\circ$.  Compute $\angle BPC - \angle BAC$.
problems.solution: Since $ABPC$ is a quadrilateral, the reflex angle of $\angle{BPC}=360^{\circ}-15^{\circ}-20^{\circ}-\angle{BAC}$, so $\angle{BPC}=15^{\circ}+20^{\circ}+\angle{BAC}$, so the answer is $35$.

problems.title: 2018 G2: Locus of Angle Bisector Foot
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a square of side length $1$, and let $P$ be a variable point on $\overline{CD}$.  Denote by $Q$ the intersection point of the angle bisector of $\angle APB$ with $\overline{AB}$.  The set of possible locations for $Q$ as $P$ varies along $\overline{CD}$ is a line segment; what is the length of this segment?
problems.solution: The extreme cases for where $Q$ lies are when $P$ is at $C$ or $D$. When $P$ is at $C$, we can use angle bisector theorem to deduce that $Q$ is $\sqrt{2}-1$ from $B$. By symmetry, when $P$ is at $D$, $Q$ is $\sqrt{2}-1$ from $A$. Since $Q$ has to be at least $\sqrt{2}-1$ distance from $A$ and $B$, the answer is $1-2(\sqrt{2}-1)=3-2\sqrt{2}$.

problems.title: 2018 G3: Extended Law of Sines
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with side lengths $5$, $4\sqrt 2$, and $7$.  What is the area of the triangle with side lengths $\sin A$, $\sin B$, and $\sin C$?
problems.solution: You can use Law of Cosines to get the angle opposite of side $5$ is $45^{\circ}$, so the ratio of the new to original triangles areas is $(\sin{45^{\circ}})^2$ divides by $5^2$ is $\frac{1}{50}$. The original triangle has area $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4\sqrt{2} \cdot 7 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=14$. The new area is $\frac{14}{50}=\frac{7}{25}$.

problems.title: 2018 G4: Composition of Rotations
problems.text: Suppose $\overline{AB}$ is a segment of unit length in the plane. Let $f(X)$ and $g(X)$ be functions of the plane such that $f$ corresponds to rotation about $A$ $60^\circ$ counterclockwise and $g$ corresponds to rotation about $B$ $90^\circ$ clockwise. Let $P$ be a point with $g(f(P))=P$; what is the sum of all possible distances from $P$ to line $AB$?
problems.solution: We proceed using complex numbers. Let $A$ be $0$ and $B$ be $1$. Let $P=p$ be desired point. When we rotate $60^{\circ}$ across $A$, we have a new point $q$ where $q=pe^{\frac{\pi \cdot i}{3}}$. When we rotate $q$ $-90^{\circ}$ across $B$, we are back to $p$, so $p-1=e^{-\frac{\pi \cdot i}{2}}(q-1)$. Substituting in $q$ in terms of $p$, we want to find the absolute value of the imaginary coordinate of $p$ because that's the distance from the $x$-axis, so the answer is $\frac{1+\sqrt{3}}{2}$.

problems.title: 2018 G5: Isodynamic Point in 3D
problems.text: Select points $T_1,T_2$ and $T_3$ in $\mathbb{R}^3$ such that $T_1=(0,1,0)$, $T_2$ is at the origin, and $T_3=(1,0,0)$. Let $T_0$ be a point on the line $x=y=0$ with $T_0\neq T_2$. Suppose there exists a point $X$ in the plane of $\triangle T_1T_2T_3$ such that the quantity $(XT_i)[T_{i+1}T_{i+2}T_{i+3}]$ is constant for all $i=0$ to $i=3$, where $[\mathcal{P}]$ denotes area of the polygon $\mathcal{P}$ and indices are taken modulo 4.  What is the magnitude of the $z$-coordinate of $T_0$?
problems.solution: Let the coordinates of the points $X$ and $T_0$ be $(x,z,0)$ and $(0,0,y)$. Obviously by symmetry, $x = z$. Now, we also have the equations $\frac{(2x^2+y^2)}{4} = (x^2+(1-x)^2) \cdot \frac{y^2}{4} = x^2 \cdot (y^2+\frac{1}{2})$. The first equality implies $y^2 = \frac{2x}{x-1}$. Plugging this back into the second equality yields $x^2 = \frac{1}{4}$ so $x = \pm\frac{1}{2}$. If $x = \frac{1}{2}$, then $y^2 < 0$, so $x = \frac{-1}{2}$ and $y = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.

problems.title: 2018 G6: Tangent Circles and Lines
problems.text: Let $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ be intersecting circles in the plane with radii $12$ and $15$, respectively. Suppose $\Gamma$ is a circle such that $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ are internally tangent to $\Gamma$ at $X_1$ and $X_2$, respectively. Similarly, $\ell$ is a line that is tangent to $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ at $Y_1$ and $Y_2$, respectively. If $X_1X_2=18$ and $Y_1Y_2=9$, what is the radius of $\Gamma$?
problems.solution:
let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be centers of two circles. Let $O$ be center of big circle. You can shift $Y_1Y_2$ down to $O_1Z$, where $Z$ is on $O_2Y_2$ such that $O_1Z$ is parallel to $Y_1Y_2$. Since $O_2Z=O_2Y_2-Y_2Z=O_2Y_2-O_1Y_1=3$ and $O_1Z=9$, use Pythag to get $O_1O_2=3\sqrt{10}$.

Let $R$ be radius of $\Gamma$. Since $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ are tangent to $\Gamma$, $O$, $O_1$, and $X_1$ are collinear while $O$, $O_2$, and $X_2$ are collinear.

Since $X_1X_2=18$, $OX_1=OX_2=R$, we can write $\angle{X_1OX_2}$ in terms of $R$ and $18$. ($\sin{\angle{X_1OX_2}}=\frac{9}{R}$). Then using $O_1O_2=3\sqrt{10}$, $OO_1=R-12$, $OO_2=R-15$, we can use Law of Cosines to find $R$. ($(R-12)^2+(R-15)^2-2(R-12)(R-15)\cos{2\angle{X_1OX_2}}=90$, so $R=18+2\sqrt{21}$.)

problems.title: 2018 G7: Equilateral Triangle on Circumcircle
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=10$, $AC=11$, and circumradius $6$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are located on the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$ such that $\triangle ADE$ is equilateral.  Line segments $\overline{DE}$ and $\overline{BC}$ intersect at $X$.  Find $\tfrac{BX}{XC}$.
problems.solution:
This is a trig bash solution sketch that can be divided into several steps.

Finding BE$BE$ is easy to find because $AE=6\sqrt{3}$ (using fact that $\frac{AE}{\sin{60^{\circ}}}=12$, $AB=10$, and $\angle{ABE}=120^{\circ}$. So using Law of Cosines on $\triangle{ABE}$ we get $BE=\sqrt{33}-5$.

Finding CESince $CD+CE=CA=11$ (well known lemma from Ptolemy Theorem), we set $CE=x$ and $CD=11-x$. Since $\angle{DCE}=120^{\circ}$, we deduce that $CE=\frac{11-\sqrt{69}}{2}$.

Finding Angle CED$\sin{\angle{CED}}=\sin{\angle{CAD}}=\sin(120^{\circ}+\angle{CBA})$. Since $\frac{11}{\sin{\angle{CBA}}}=12$, we can use basic trig to get $\sin{\angle{CED}}=\frac{11+\sqrt{69}}{24}$.

Finding Angle DEB$\sin{\angle{DEB}}=\sin{\angle{DAB}}=\sin(60^{\circ}+\angle{ACB})$. Since $\frac{10}{\sin{\angle{ACB}}}=12$, we can use basic trig to get $\sin{\angle{DEB}}=\frac{\sqrt{33}+5}{12}$.

Putting it all togetherUsing Ratio Lemma, $\frac{CX}{XB}=\frac{BE}{CE} \cdot \frac{\sin{\angle{DEB}}}{\sin{\angle{CED}}}=\frac{8}{13}$.

problems.title: 2018 G8: External Semicircles and Spiral Similarity
problems.text: In quadrilateral $ABCD$, $AB=2$, $AD=3$, $BC=CD=\sqrt7$, and $\angle DAB=60^\circ$. Semicircles $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$ are erected on the exterior of the quadrilateral with diameters $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AD}$; points $E\neq B$ and $F\neq D$ are selected on $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$ respectively such that $\triangle CEF$ is equilateral. What is the area of $\triangle CEF$?
problems.solution:
Firstly, we nee that $\triangle$$CDB$ is equilateral with side length $\sqrt{7}.$ So, as equilateral triangles are symmetric with respect to any vertex, there exists a spiral similarity between $\triangle$$CBD$ and $\triangle$$CEF.$ So, by the definition of spiral similarity, we get $DF = BE.$ Then, translate by vector $BD$ and denote the image by $E'.$ Then, triangle $\triangle$$DFE$ becomes equilateral as $DF = DE',$ and additionally, $\angle{(DF, DE')} = \angle{(DF, BE)} = 60^\circ.$ Let $\Phi$ denote the transformation of the plane corresponding to a $60^\circ$ rotation about point $C.$ We let the result of $\Phi(A) = A^{*}.$ Note that $\angle{A^{*}DA} = 120^\circ$ because the transformation $\Phi$ brings $AB$ to $A^{*}D$ and we already have $\angle{BAD} = 60^\circ.$ Then, we get that $\triangle$$A^{*}FD \cong \triangle{AEB}$ as one triangle is brought to the other by $\Phi.$ This congruence implies

(a) $F$ is the foot of the altitude from $D$ to $AA^{*}$

(b) $A^{*}F = AE$

(c) $\angle{EAF} = 120^\circ.$

Then, we can use the law of cosines to get $AA* = \sqrt{19},$ and as the two triangles share a base, we can use the fact that the areas are proportional to the bases, to get $DF = \sqrt{\frac{27}{19}}.$

Again by the law of cosines, we get $EF^2 = AF^2 + AE^2 + AE \cdot AF = AF^2 + A^{*}F^2 + AF \cdot A^{*}F$

$= (AF + A^{*}F)^2 - AF \cdot A^{*}F = (\sqrt{19})^2 - \sqrt{4 - \frac{27}{19}}\sqrt{9 - \frac{27}{19}} = 19 - \frac{7\cdot 12}{19} = \frac{277}{19}.$ By the formula for the area of an equilateral triangle given the side length, we get that the final answer if $\boxed{\frac{277\sqrt{3}}{76}}.$

problems.title: 2018 G9: Confocal Ellipses
problems.text: Suppose $\mathcal{E}_1 \neq \mathcal{E}_2$ are two intersecting ellipses with a common focus $X$; let the common external tangents of $\mathcal{E}_1$ and $\mathcal{E}_2$ intersect at a point $Y$. Further suppose that $X_1$ and $X_2$ are the other foci of $\mathcal{E}_1$ and $\mathcal{E}_2$, respectively, such that $X_1\in \mathcal{E}_2$ and $X_2\in \mathcal{E}_1$. If $X_1X_2=8, XX_2=7$, and $XX_1=9$, what is $XY^2$?
problems.solution:
Let the external tangents be $\ell_1,\ell_2$. Do the reflection trick - reflect $X$ over $\ell_1,\ell_2$ to $A,B$. Then $X_1A=X_1B=\kappa_1$, $X_2A=X_2B=\kappa_2$ where $\kappa_1=15,\kappa_2=17$ are the fixed sum constants of $\mathcal{E}_1,\mathcal{E}_2$. Then $Y$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle{AXB}$ because $\ell_1,\ell_2$ are perpendicular bisectors of $XA,XB$.



Now, observe that the circles centered at $X_1,X_2$ with radii $\kappa_1,\kappa_2$ intersect at $A,B$, so $X_1X_2$ is the perpendicular bisector of $AB$. Since $Y$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle{AXB}$, $Y$ must be on $X_1X_2$.



Now, we have the Stewart's Theorem configuration in $\triangle{YXX_2}$. Determining $XY$ is equivalent to computing $X_1Y$. To do this, we compute $\frac{X_1Y}{X_2Y}$. Project $X,X_1,X_2$ onto $\ell_1$ to $X',X_1',X_2'$. First, consider a triangle $YCD$ with inellipse $\mathcal{E}_1$ (so $X,X_1$ are isogonal conjugates in $\triangle{YCD}$). Construct the $6$-point circle of $YCD$ based on $X,X_1$, call it $\mathcal{C}_1$ with radius $\frac{\kappa_1}{2}$. Choose point $X_1^*$ such that $X_1'X_1X_1^*X$ is a parallelogram, then $X_1^*\in\mathcal{C}_1$. Then \[XX'\cdot X_1X_1'=XX'\cdot XX_1^*=\left|\rho\left(X,\mathcal{X}_1\right)\right|=\frac{\kappa_1^2}{4}-\frac{XX_1^2}{4}.\]Similarly, $XX'\cdot X_2X_2'=\frac{\kappa_2^2}{4}-\frac{XX_2^2}{4}$. Then \[\frac{X_1Y}{X_2Y}=\frac{XX'\cdot X_1X_1'}{XX'\cdot X_2X_2'}=\frac{\kappa_1^2-XX_1^2}{\kappa_2^2-XX_2^2}=\frac{12}{20},\]so $X_1Y=12$. Use Stewart's to finish the problem off, getting $XY^2=\boxed{369}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB A1: Fractional Parts of Powers
problems.text: For all real numbers $r$, denote by $\{r\}$ the fractional part of $r$, i.e. the unique real number $s\in[0,1)$ such that $r-s$ is an integer.  How many real numbers $x\in[1,2)$ satisfy the equation $\left\{x^{2018}\right\} = \left\{x^{2017}\right\}?$
problems.solution: Y by Williamgolly, Adventure10, Mango247Note that the condition implies that $x^{2018}-x^{2017} \in \mathbb{Z}$. Note that for $x \in [1,2)$ the function $f(x) = x^{2018} - x^{2017}$ is continuous and ranges from $[0, 2^{2017} )$. Therefore by IVT the total number of solutions is $\boxed{2^{2017}}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB A2: Sum of Digits of Product
problems.text: Compute the sum of the digits of \[\prod_{n=0}^{2018}\left(10^{2\cdot 3^n} - 10^{3^n} + 1\right)\left(10^{2\cdot 3^n} + 10^{3^n} + 1\right).\]
problems.solution:
Note $\left(10^{2\cdot 3^n} - 10^{3^n} + 1\right)\left(10^{2\cdot 3^n} + 10^{3^n} + 1\right) = 10^{4\cdot 3^n} + 10^{2\cdot 3^n} + 1$, which looks complicated, but once you play around a little, you notice the product of all numbers of this form follows a really obviously pattern ($101010\ldots1010101$)*. Noting there are $1 + 4\cdot 3^0 + 4\cdot 3^1 + \cdots 4\cdot 3^{2018} = 2\cdot 3^{2019} - 1$ digits, which gives a digital sum of $\boxed{3^{2019}}$.



*This pattern can be proven by noting:

\[ 10^{4\cdot 3^n} + 10^{2\cdot 3^n} + 1 = \frac{10^{6\cdot 3^n} - 1}{10^{2\cdot 3^n}-1} \]and telescoping.

problems.title: 2018 TB A3: Symmetric Expression in Roots of Polynomial
problems.text: Let $a$ be a complex number, and set $\alpha$, $\beta$, and $\gamma$ to be the roots of the polynomial $x^3 - x^2 + ax - 1$.  Suppose \[(\alpha^3+1)(\beta^3+1)(\gamma^3+1) = 2018.\]Compute the product of all possible values of $a$.
problems.solution:
Nice Problem! It's pretty standard though in my opinion.



Let $-1, \omega_1 = e^{i \pi/6}$ and $\omega_2 = e^{5i \pi/6}$ be the roots of the polynomial $x^3+1=0$. Then

\[(\alpha^3+1)(\beta^3+1)(\gamma^3+1) = \prod_{cyc} (\alpha+1)(\alpha - \omega)(\alpha-\omega_2)\]Let $f(x) = x^3-x^2+ax-1$. Then this expressions is equal to $-f(-1)f(\omega_1)f(\omega_2)$. Using our roots of unity skills we see that $f(-1) = -\alpha-3, f(\omega_1)=\omega_1(\alpha+1)-1$ and $f(\omega_2) = \omega_2(\alpha-1)-1$. Multiplying and simplifying the roots of unity we see the product is equal to

\[-f(-1)f(\omega_1)f(\omega_2) = (\alpha+3)(\alpha^2-3\alpha+3)\]Therefore we have $ (\alpha+3)(\alpha^2-3\alpha+3) = 2018$ so the product of all the possible values of $\alpha$ is $2018-9 = \boxed{2009}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB C1: Divisible by 11
problems.text: How many nonnegative integers with at most $40$ digits consisting of entirely zeroes and ones are divisible by $11$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Let $n = \sum_{n=0}^{39} a_n \cdot 10^n$ where $a_n \in \{0,1 \}$. Notice that $n \equiv  \sum_{n=0}^{39} a_n \cdot (-1)^n \pmod{11}$. Therefore, $n \equiv 0\pmod{11}$ if and only if

\[ \left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n}\right)-\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n+1}\right) \equiv 0 \pmod{11} \]

Case 1: $\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n}\right)-\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n+1}\right)=0$

There are $\binom{20}{k}$ ways to insert $k$ ones among the set $\{a_0, a_2, \dots, a_{20}\}$ and similarly $\binom{20}{k}$ ways to insert $k$ ones among the set $\{a_1, a_3, \dots, a_{39}\}$. Therefore, the total number of ways is $\sum_{k=0}^{20} \binom{20}{k}^2 = \binom{40}{20}$.
Case 2:$\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n}\right)-\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n+1}\right)=\pm 11$

It suffices to count the number of ways the difference can be $11$ since switching all the $0's$ for $1's$ and $1's$ for $0's$ creates a new number with difference $-11$. Then there are $\binom{20}{k}$ ways to insert $k$ ones among the set $\{a_0, a_2, \dots, a_{20} \}$ and $\binom{20}{k+11} = \binom{20}{9-k}$ ways to insert $k+11$ ones among the set $\{a_1, a_3, \cdots a_{39}  \}$. Therefore, the total number of ways is $2 \cdot \sum_{k=0}^9 \binom{20}{k} \binom{20}{9-k} = 2 \cdot \binom{40}{9}$.
Case 3:$\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n}\right)-\left(\sum_{n=0}^{19}a_{2n+1}\right)=\pm 22$

Clearly this is impossible since the minimum and maximum values of the difference are $0-20 = -20$ and $20+0 = 20$ respectively.

Therefore, the total number of integers is $\boxed{\binom{40}{20} + 2 \cdot \binom{40}{9}}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB C3: Set Differences
problems.text: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of subsets of $\{1,2,\ldots, 2017\}$ with the following property: if $S_1$ and $S_2$ are two elements of $\mathcal{F}$ with $S_1\subsetneq S_2$, then $|S_2\setminus S_1|$ is odd. Compute the largest number of subsets $\mathcal{F}$ may contain.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247It is obvious that there cannot exist $A \subsetneq B \subsetneq C$ in $\mathcal{F}$. By a simple modification to the proof of the LYM inequality,

\[\sum_{S \in \mathcal{F}} \binom{2017}{|S|}^{-1} \le 2 \implies |\mathcal{F}| \le 2 \binom{2017}{1008}.\]Equality is achieved when $\mathcal{F}$ contains all the 1008-subsets and 1009-subsets of $\{1, \dots, 2017\}$; the answer is $\boxed{2 \tbinom{2017}{1008}}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB G2: Trapezoid with External Angle Bisector
problems.text: Suppose $ABCD$ is a trapezoid with $AB\parallel CD$ and $AB\perp BC$. Let $X$ be a point on segment $\overline{AD}$ such that $AD$ bisects $\angle BXC$ externally, and denote $Y$ as the intersection of $AC$ and $BD$. If $AB=10$ and $CD=15$, compute the maximum possible value of $XY$.
problems.solution:
Let $r=\frac{AX}{DX}$ and $E=BX \cap CD$. From $ABX \sim DEX$, we get $\frac{CD}{DE}=\frac{3r}{2-2r}$. Let $CX \cap AB = F$ and $z=BC$. Then $\frac{CD}{DE}=\frac{CX}{XE}=\frac{CF}{BE}$. Using Pythagorean Theorem and simplifying, we find $z^2=\frac{125(2+r)}{(2-5r)}$.



Now we use coordinates. Let $A=(5,z), B=(15,z), C=(15,0), D=(0,0)$. Then $X=\left( 5(1-r), (1-r)z \right)$ and $Y=\left( 9, \frac{3}{5}z \right)$. Using Pythagorean Theorem, $XY^2=(5r+4)^2+\frac{z^2(2-5r)^2}{25}=(4+5r)^2+5(2+r)(2-5r)=36$, so the length is always $\boxed{6}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB G3: Altitude in Intouch Triangle
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with incircle $\omega$ and incenter $I$.  The circle $\omega$ is tangent to $BC$, $CA$, and $AB$ at $D$, $E$, and $F$ respectively.  Point $P$ is the foot of the angle bisector from $A$ to $BC$, and point $Q$ is the foot of the altitude from $D$ to $EF$. Suppose $AI=7$, $IP=5$, and $DQ=4$.  Compute the radius of $\omega$.
problems.solution: It's well known that $\frac{AI}{IP} = \frac{b+c}{a}$ and if $M$ is the midpoint of minor arc $BC$, $\frac{AI}{IM} = \frac{b+c-a}{a}$. Now, $\frac{AI}{IM} = \frac{AI}{IP} - 1 = \frac{2}{5}$, so $IM = \frac{35}{2}$ and $AI_A = 42$. The power of $I$ with respect to the circumcircle is $2Rr = AI \cdot IM = \frac{245}{2}$. Since $DEF$ is similar to $I_AI_BI_C$ in the ratio $\frac{r}{2R}$, we also have $\frac{r}{R} = \frac{4}{21}$. Thus, $r^2 = \frac{245}{21} = \frac{35}{3}$, and $r = \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{105}}{3}}$.

problems.title: 2018 TB NT2: Solutions to Equation Modulo 71
problems.text: How many integer values of $k$, with $1 \leq k \leq 70$, are such that $x^{k}-1 \equiv 0 \pmod{71}$ has at least $\sqrt{k}$ solutions?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10That has $\gcd(70, k)$ solutions. So we want to find $k$ such that $\gcd(70, k) \ge \sqrt{k}$. Let's do a bit of casework:

$$\gcd(k, 70) = 1: 1 \implies 1 $$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 2: 2, 4 \implies 2$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 5: 5, 15, 25 \implies 3$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 7: 7,  21, 49 \implies 3$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 10: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 \implies 6$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 35: 35 \implies 1$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 14: 14, 28, 42, 56 \implies 4$$$$\gcd(k, 70) = 70: 70 \implies 1$$Therefore, the answer is $1 + 2 + 3 + 3 + 6 + 1 + 4 + 1 = 21$.

problems.title: 2018 TB NT3: Quadratic Residue Pairs
problems.text: Determine the number of integers $a$ with $1\leq a\leq 1007$ and the property that both $a$ and $a+1$ are quadratic residues mod $1009$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247This is asking some variant of the number of solutions to $x^2 \equiv 1 + y^2 \pmod{1009}$. That's equal to

$$\sum_{y = 0}^{1008} \left(1 + \left(\frac{y}{1009}\right)\right)\left(1 +  \left(\frac{1 + y}{1009}\right)\right)$$Expanding this out, and using the trick

$$\left(\frac{y}{1009}\right) = \left(\frac{y^{-1}}{1009}\right)$$we get that the sum is $1008$. However, this counts both $-1$ and $0$, and worse off, some solutions are doubled, and some quadrupled. The ones that are doubled are the ones we don't care about: $(1, 0)$ and $(0, i)$. The ones that are quadrupled are ones we do care about. So let's subtract $4$ off of $1008$ to get $1004$, and the correct answer would be $\frac{1004}{4} = 251$

problems.title: 2018 A2: Sum of a Number and its Reciprocal
problems.text: Suppose $x>1$ is a real number such that $x+\tfrac 1x = \sqrt{22}$.  What is $x^2-\tfrac1{x^2}$?
problems.solution: Notice that $\left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)^2  = \left(x - \frac{1}{x}\right)^2 + 4,$ so $x - \frac{1}{x} = \sqrt{18}.$ So, we can multiply the two equations to get $\left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x - \frac{1}{x}\right) = x^2 - \frac{1}{x^2} = \sqrt{18}\sqrt{22} = \boxed{6\sqrt{11}}.$

problems.title: 2018 A3: Product of Real Solutions
problems.text: Let $P(x)=x^2+4x+1$.  What is the product of all real solutions to the equation $P(P(x))=0$?
problems.solution:
The quadratic formula gives that the roots of $P$ are $-2 \pm \sqrt{3}$. Next, we know that if $y$ is a root, then $P(y) = -2 + \sqrt{3}$ or $P(y) = -2 -\sqrt{3}$.



Case 1: $P(y)=-2 + \sqrt{3}$.



Then $y^2 + 4y + 3 - \sqrt{3} = 0$. A quick discriminant check yields that the roots are real in this case, so we get that the product of the roots is $3 -\sqrt{3}$.



Case 2: $P(y) = -2 -\sqrt{3}$.



Then $y^2 + 4y + 3 + \sqrt{3} = 0$. The discriminant is negative, so there are no real roots.



The answer is $3 - \sqrt{3}$.

problems.title: 2018 A5: Antisymmetric System of Equations
problems.text: Suppose $a$, $b$, and $c$ are nonzero real numbers such that \[bc+\frac1a = ca+\frac2b = ab+\frac7c = \frac1{a+b+c}.\]Find $a+b+c$.
problems.solution:
We have $bc + \tfrac{1}{a} = \tfrac{1}{a+b+c} \implies abc + 1 = \tfrac{a}{a+b+c}$.



Performing similar operations yields $3abc + 10 = 1 \implies abc = -3$.



Next, we multiply the three equations together, yielding $(abc)^2 + 10abc + 23 + \tfrac{14}{abc} = \tfrac{1}{(a+b+c)^3}$. It follows that $9- 30 + 23 - \tfrac{14}{3} = \tfrac{1}{(a+b+c)^3}$, so our answer is $- \tfrac{3^{1/3}}{2}$.

problems.title: 2018 A6: Minimal Fibonacci Representations
problems.text: We call $\overline{a_n\ldots a_2}$ the Fibonacci representation of a positive integer $k$ if \[k = \sum_{i=2}^n a_i F_i,\]where $a_i\in\{0,1\}$ for all $i$, $a_n=1$, and $F_i$ denotes the $i^{\text{th}}$ Fibonacci number ($F_0=0$, $F_1=1$, and $F_i=F_{i-1}+F_{i-2}$ for all $i\ge2$). This representation is said to be $\textit{minimal}$ if it has fewer 1’s than any other Fibonacci representation of $k$. Find the smallest positive integer that has eight ones in its minimal Fibonacci representation.
problems.solution:
Note that if two or more consecutive Fibonacci numbers $F_{i}, F_{i+1}, \ldots, F_{i+k}$ are included in the sum, then it is not minimal, as we can construct a smaller representation with $F_{i+k-1} + F_{i+k} = F_{i+k+1}$. Hence any minimal Fibonacci representation cannot use consecutive Fibonacci numbers. With this in mind, the smallest positive integer that has eight ones in its Fibonacci representation would then be $F_2 + F_4 + F_6 + \cdots + F_{16} = F_{17} - 1 = \boxed{1596}$.



In addition, any Fibonacci representation with no two consecutive Fibonacci numbers is guaranteed to be minimal by uniqueness from Zeckendorf's theorem.

problems.title: 2018 A7: Sum of Cosines
problems.text:
Compute

\[\sum_{k=0}^{2017}\dfrac{5+\cos\left(\frac{\pi k}{1009}\right)}{26+10\cos\left(\frac{\pi k}{1009}\right)}.\]
problems.solution: Let $z=e^{\pi i / 1009}.$ Then $\sum_{k=0}^{2017}\dfrac{5+\cos\left(\frac{\pi k}{1009}\right)}{26+10\cos\left(\frac{\pi k}{1009}\right)}=\sum_{k=0}^{2017}\dfrac{10+z^k+z^{-k}}{52+10z^k+10z^{-k}}=\sum_{k=0}^{2017}\dfrac{(5+z^k)+(5+z^{-k})}{2(5+z^k)(5+z^{-k})}=\sum_{k=0}^{2017}\dfrac{1}{2(5+z^{-k})}+\dfrac{1}{2(5+z^k)}.$ Reindexing the second term, this is equal to $\sum_{i=0}^{2017}\dfrac{1}{5+z^k}.$ But $\dfrac{1}{5+z^k}$ are roots of the equation $(1/x-5)^{2018}-1=0\implies (1-5x)^{2018}-x^{2018}=1.$ This is a polynomial in $x,$ so we calculate the sum of the roots to be $\dfrac{2018\cdot 5^{2017}}{5^{2018}-1}$

problems.title: 2018 A8: Cubic Polynomial Inequality
problems.text: Suppose $P$ is a cubic polynomial satisfying $P(0) = 3$ and \[(x^3 - 2x + 1 - P(x))(2x^3 - 5x^2 + 4 - P(x))\leq 0\]for all $x\in\mathbb R$.  Determine all possible values of $P(-1)$.
problems.solution: Note that for all $x$ satsifying $x^3-2x+1=2x^3-5x^2+4,$ the expression on the left is a perfect square, so $P(x)$ must be equal to this common value. But this rearranges to $Q(x)\stackrel{\text{def}}{=}x^3-5x^2+2x+3=0$ which notably has three real roots since $Q(-10)<0,$ $Q(1)>0,$ $Q(2)<0,$ $Q(10)>0.$ Then if these roots are $r_1,r_2,r_3,$ we know that $P(r_i)=r_i^3-2r_i+1$ for $1\leq i \leq 3,$ implying that $P(x)-x^3+2x-1 = R(x)(x-r_1)(x-r_2)(x-r_3).$ But $P(x)$ has degree $3$ so we need $R(x)$ to be a constant, and plugging in $x=0$ yields $R(x)=\dfrac{2}{3}.$ Now simply substituting $x=-1$ yields the unique answer of $-\dfrac{4}{3}.$

problems.title: 2018 A9: Sum of Squares of Coefficients
problems.text: Suppose $a_0,a_1,\ldots, a_{2018}$ are integers such that \[(x^2-3x+1)^{1009} = \sum_{k=0}^{2018}a_kx^k\]for all real numbers $x$.  Compute the remainder when $a_0^2 + a_1^2 + \cdots + a_{2018}^2$ is divided by $2017$.
problems.solution:
Y by PARISsaintGERMAIN, tapir1729, rzlng, Williamgolly, Adventure10Since the polynomial is symmetric, we just want the $a_0a_{2018} + a_1a_{2017} + \cdots$, which is the $x^{2018}$ coefficient of $(x^2-3x+1)^{2018}$, which is just, by Multinomial, \[
\sum_{0\leq a\leq 1009} \binom{2018}{a,a,2018-2a} (-3)^{2018-a} = \sum_{0\leq a \leq 1009} \frac{2018!}{a!a!(2018-2a)!}3^{2018-2a},
\]which vanishes modulo $2017$ unless $a = 0$ (since we need one of $a,a,2018-2a$ to be at least $2017$). So, our answer is just $3^{2018} \equiv \boxed{9}$ modulo $2017$.

problems.title: 2018 A10: Maximum Number of Irreducible Factors
problems.text: Define a sequence of polynomials $F_n(x)$ by $F_0(x)=0, F_1(x)=x-1$, and for $n\geq 1$, $$F_{n+1}(x)=2xF_n(x)-F_{n-1}(x)+2F_1(x).$$For each $n$, $F_n(x)$ can be written in the form $$F_n(x)=c_nP_1(x)P_2(x)\cdots P_{g(n)}(x)$$where $c_n$ is a constant and $P_1(x),P_2(x)\cdots, P_{g(n)}(x)$ are non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients and $g(n)$ is as large as possible. For all $2< n< 101$, let $t$ be the minimum possible value of $g(n)$ in the above expression; for how many $k$ in the specified range is $g(k)=t$?
problems.solution:
Let $G_n(x) = F_n(x) + 1$; then the recursion is $G_0(x) = 0$, $G_1(x) = x$, and $G_{n + 1}(x) = 2x G_n(x) - G_{n - 1}(x)$. It follows that $\{G_n\}$ are the Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind: $G_n(\cos t) = \cos nt$, or $G_n(\tfrac{t + t^{-1}}{2}) = \tfrac{t^n + t^{-n}}{2}$. Thus $F_n(\tfrac{t + t^{-1}}{2}) = \tfrac{t^n + t^{-n}}{2} - 1$.



We contend that $g(n) \ge 3$ for all $n \ge 3$, and $g(n) = 3$ exactly when $n$ is an odd prime. Since we are excluding constant factors, we may instead analyze the polynomial $H_p$ defined by $H_p(2x) = 2F_p(x)$ (so $H_p(t + \tfrac{1}{t}) = t^p + \tfrac{1}{t^p} - 2$).



Then note that 2 is always a root of $H_p$, and

\[\frac{H_n(t + t^{-1})}{t + t^{-1} - 2} = \frac{t^n + t^{-n} - 2}{t + t^{-1} - 2} = \frac{(t^n - 1)(t^{-n} - 1)}{(t - 1)(t^{-1} - 1)} = (1 + t + \dots + t^{n - 1})(1 + t^{-1} + \dots + t^{-(n - 1)}).\]

If $n \ge 3$ is odd, we have

\[\frac{H_n(t + t^{-1})}{t + t^{-1} - 2} = \left(t^{-(n - 1)/2} + \dots + t^{(n - 1)/2}\right)^2.\]Hence $\tfrac{H_n(x)}{x - 2}$ is the square of a polynomial $P_n$. If $n$ is prime, then $P_n$ is a (scaled) cyclotomic polynomial of order $n$ and is irreducible, so $g(n) = 3$. If $n$ is composite, then $t^{-(n - 1)/2} + \dots + t^{(n - 1)/2}$ factors further in $\mathbb{Z}[t + t^{-1}]$, and so $g(n) \ge 5$.

If $n \ge 4$ is even,

\begin{align*}
\frac{H_n(t + t^{-1})}{t + t^{-1} - 2} = (1 + t + \dots + t^{n - 1})(1 + t^{-1} + \dots + t^{-(n - 1)}) & = (1 + t)(1 + t^{-1}) (1 + t^2 + \dots + t^{n - 2}) (1 + t^{-2} + \dots + t^{-(n - 2)})\\
& = (t + t^{-1} + 2) \left(t^{-(n - 2)/2} + t^{-(n - 4)/2} + \dots + t^{(n - 2)/2}\right)^2.
\end{align*}It follows that $H_n(x) = (x - 2)(x + 2)P_n(x)^2$ for some nontrivial polynomial $P_n$, so $g(n) \ge 4$.

We have shown that $g(n) \ge 3$ when $n \ge 3$, with equality exactly when $n$ is an (odd) prime. The number of primes between 3 and 100 inclusive is $\boxed{24}$.

problems.title: 2018 NT1: System of Equations
problems.text: Suppose $a$, $b$, and $c$ are relatively prime integers such that \[\frac{a}{b+c} = 2\qquad\text{and}\qquad \frac{b}{a+c} = 3.\]What is $|c|$?
problems.solution: Use your fraction manipulation skills to get $\frac{b}{a+b+c}=\frac{3}{4}$ and $\frac{a}{a+b+c}=\frac{2}{3}$. Therefore, $\frac{c}{a+b+c}=1-\frac{3}{4}-\frac{2}{3}=\frac{-5}{12}$. Since $a$, $b$, $c$ are relatively prime integers, we multiply by $a+b+c=12$ to the three equations to get $b=9$, $a=8$, and $c=-5$. So answer is $5$.
