problems.title: 2018 NT6: Euler Totient Function Divides N
problems.text: Let $\phi(n)$ denote the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ that are coprime to $n$. Find the sum of all $1<n<100$ such that $\phi(n)\mid n$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Let $n=p_1^{e_1}p_2^{e_2}p_3^{e_3} \cdots$. Note that $\phi(n)=(p_1-1)p^{e_1-1} (p_2-1)p_2^{e_2-1}(p_3-1)p_3^{e_3-1} \cdots$. Therefore, if $\phi(n) \mid n$ then $(p_1-1)(p_2-1)(p_3-1) \cdots \mid p_1p_2p_3 \cdots$. Clearly $n$ can have any power of $2$ as a factor since $2-1=1$. Also, if $v_2(n) \ge 1$ then $n$ can clearly have any power of $3$ as a factor. Note that $n$ cannot have more than $2$ odd prime factors since the maximum power of $2$ that can divide $p_1p_2p_3 \cdots$ is $2$. Therefore, the only possible odd prime factor of $n$ is $2^1+1=3$.



Hence, all the possible values can be expressed as $2^{e_1} 3^{e_2}$ where $e_1 \ge 1$. Summing we get

\[\left(1+3+9\right)\cdot\left(2+4+8\right)+\left(16+32\right)\cdot\left(1+3\right)+64+54 = \boxed{492} \]

problems.title: 2018 NT9: Euler Totient Generating Function
problems.text: Let $\phi(n)$ denote the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ that are coprime to $n$. Compute \[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\phi(n)}{5^n+1}.\]
problems.solution:
Y by Einstein314, tapir1729, Vfire, Adventure10We have

\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\phi(n)}{5^n+1}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\phi(n)\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{m+1}}{5^{mn}}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{5^n}\sum_{d\mid n}\phi(d)(-1)^{\frac{n}{d}+1}.\]If $n$ is odd, then

\[\sum_{d\mid n}\phi(d)(-1)^{\frac{n}{d}+1}=\sum_{d\mid n}\phi(d)=n.\]If $n=2^kq$, where $q$ is odd and $k\geq 1$, then

\[\sum_{d\mid n}\phi(d)(-1)^{\frac{n}{d}+1}=\sum_{\text{odd }d\mid n}(-\phi(d)-\phi(2d)-\dotsb+\phi(2^kd))=0.\](The second sum is over all odd divisors of $n$.) Hence

\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\phi(n)}{5^n+1}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{2k+1}{5^{2k+1}}=\boxed{\frac{65}{288}}.\]details for the last computationWe have

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{5}+\frac{1}{5^3}+\frac{1}{5^5}+\frac{1}{5^7}+\dotsb &= \frac{5}{24} \\
\frac{2}{5^3}+\frac{2}{5^5}+\frac{2}{5^7}+\dotsb &= \frac{1}{60} \\
\frac{2}{5^5}+\frac{2}{5^7}+\dotsb &= \frac{1}{25\times 60} \\
\frac{2}{5^7}+\dotsb &= \frac{1}{25^2\times 60} \\
&\vdots
\end{align*}Add up all of these to obtain

\[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{2k+1}{5^{2k+1}}=\frac{5}{24}+\frac{1}{60}\left(1+\frac{1}{25}+\frac{1}{25^2}+\dotsb\right)=\frac{5}{24}+\frac{1}{60}\times\frac{25}{24}=\frac{65}{288}.\]

problems.title: 2018 NT10: Discriminant of Cyclotomic Polynomial
problems.text: Let $a_1 < a_2 < \cdots < a_k$ denote the sequence of all positive integers between $1$ and $91$ which are relatively prime to $91$, and set $\omega = e^{2\pi i/91}$. Define \[S = \prod_{1\leq q < p\leq k}\left(\omega^{a_p} - \omega^{a_q}\right).\]Given that $S$ is a positive integer, compute the number of positive divisors of $S$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10Personally, I think this is a little too cruel to give to high-schoolers. But then again, some high schoolers may know what the discriminant of a number field is...



Let $f(z) = \prod (x - \omega_{a_q}) = \Phi_{91}(x)$. Note that $f'(\omega_b) = \prod_{\omega_b \neq \omega_a} (\omega_{b} - \omega_a)$. So

$$\Phi_{91}(x) = \frac{\Phi_7(x^{13})}{\Phi_{7}(x)} = \frac{\frac{x^{91} - 1}{x^{13} - 1}}{\frac{x^{7} - 1}{x - 1}} = \frac{(x^{91} - 1)(x - 1)}{(x^{13} - 1)(x^7 - 1)}$$Taking the derivative, and plugging in $\omega$, we have:

$$\Phi'(\omega) = \frac{91\omega^{90}(\omega - 1)}{(\omega^{13} - 1)(\omega^7 - 1)}$$Let $G = \text{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\omega)/\mathbb{Q})$. Now just take the norm:

$$N(\omega) = 1$$$$N(\omega^{13} - 1) = \prod_{\phi \in G} (\phi(\omega)^{13} - 1) = \Phi_7(1)^{12} = 7^{12}$$$$N(\omega^{7} - 1) = 13^6$$$$N(\omega - 1) = 1$$$$N(91) = 91^{72}$$Therefore,

$$S^2 = N(f'(\omega)) = \frac{91^{72}}{13^6 \cdot 7^{12}} = 13^{66} \cdot 7^{60}$$So the answer is

$$34 \times 31 = \boxed{1054}$$

problems.title: 2018 C2: Arrangements of Cubes
problems.text: Compute the number of ways to rearrange nine white cubes and eighteen black cubes into a $3\times 3\times 3$ cube such that each $1\times1\times3$ row or column contains exactly one white cube. Note that rotations are considered $\textit{distinct}$.
problems.solution: Obviously each layer of the cube must contain $3$ white cubes. For the first layer, we can arrange the blocks however we want so that no two are in the same row or column--it is easy to see there are then $6$ ways to arrange the blocks in the $1$st layer. Any white cube in the second layer will then determine the rest of the cube, so there are $\frac{6}{3} = 2$ ways to place the rest of the white cubes, giving $\boxed{12}$ total ways to rearrange the cubes.

problems.title: 2018 C3: Teleportation in a Grid
problems.text: Michelle is at the bottom-left corner of a $6\times 6$ lattice grid, at $(0,0)$. The grid also contains a pair of one-time-use teleportation devices at $(2,2)$ and $(3,3)$; the first time Michelle moves to one of these points she is instantly teleported to the other point and the devices disappear. If she can only move up or to the right in unit increments, in how many ways can she reach the point $(5,5)$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Without the teleportation devices, there are ${10\choose5}=252$ ways for Michelle to go from $(0,0)$ to $(5,5)$. Since there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{6\choose3}=120$ ways for Michelle to go through $(2,2)$ and the same number of ways for her to go through $(3,3)$, and there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{2\choose1}\cdot{4\choose2}=72$ ways for her to go through both points, there are $252-120-120+72=84$ ways for her to go through neither point. With her teleporting from $(2,2)$ to $(3,3)$, there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{4\choose2}=36$ possible paths, and with her teleporting the other way, there are $\left({6\choose3}-{4\choose2}\cdot{2\choose1}\right)\cdot{6\choose3}=160$ possible paths. Therefore, there are a total of $84+36+160=280$ possible paths for her.

problems.title: 2018 C4: Waiting for Busses
problems.text: At CMU, the A and the B buses arrive once every 20 and 18 minutes, respectively. Kevin prefers the A bus but does not want to wait for too long.  He commits to the following waiting scheme: he will take the first A bus that arrives, but after waiting for five minutes he will take the next bus that comes, no matter what it is. Determine the probability that he ends up on an A bus.
problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247We proceed using geometric probability, with the number of minutes until the first A bus arrives on the $x$-axis and that for the B bus on the $y$-axis. Since the A bus will arrive at a time randomly and uniformly selected from 0 to 20 minutes, and the B bus from 0 to 18 minutes, our sample space is $0\leq x\leq20$ and $0\leq y\leq18$, with area $360$. Kevin will end up on an A bus if $x\leq5$ or $x\leq y$. Thus, the desired area is $5\cdot18+\frac{13^2}{2}=\frac{349}{2}$, and so the probability he ends up on an A bus is $\frac{\frac{349}{2}}{360}=\frac{349}{720}$.

problems.title: 2018 C5: Shuffling the Cards
problems.text: Victor shuffles a standard 54-card deck then flips over cards one at a time onto a pile stopping after the first ace. However, if he ever reveals a joker he discards the entire pile, including the joker, and starts a new pile; for example, if the sequence of cards is 2-3-Joker-A, the pile ends with one card in it. Find the expected number of cards in the end pile.
problems.solution: Assume that Victor keeps drawing the cards until all the cards are gone and he never discards any of them. After all the cards are flipped over, the deck will contain $4$ aces and $2$ jokers which divide the deck into $7$ groups (possibly containing $0$ cards). By symmetry each group is expected to contain a total of $\tfrac{54-6}{7} = \tfrac{48}{7}$ cards. The expected number of cards in the end pile is equal to the expected number of cards in the group in the direct directly before the first ace plus the ace card itself. This is simply $\tfrac{48}{7}+1 = \boxed{\tfrac{55}{7}}$.

problems.title: 2018 C6: Rolling a Die
problems.text: Richard rolls a fair six-sided die repeatedly until he rolls his twentieth prime number or his second even number. Compute the probability that his last roll is prime.
problems.solution:
Let $E(m, n)$ be the probability Richard gets to the point where he has rolled $m$ primes and $n$ evens. The probability that Richard rolls a non-even prime should be $\frac{2}{6}$, but since $1$ is neither prime nor even, at least not in this century, we can effectively ignore all $1$'s and the probability Richard rolls a non-even prime is $\frac{2}{5}$. Similarly, the probability for rolling a composite even is $\frac{2}{5}$, and the probability of rolling an even prime is $\frac{1}{5}$.



Armed with this knowledge, we can turn this problem into a MathCounts states/dynamic problem problem and find a recursion. Note $E(0,0) = 1$, obviously, and $E(n,0) = \frac{2}{5} E(n-1,0)$, so it is easy to see that $E(n,0) = \left( \frac{2}{5} \right)^{n}$. Also, $E(0, 1) = \frac{2}{5}$.



Finally, note $E(m, n) = \frac{2}{5} E(m, n-1) + \frac{1}{5} E(m-1, n-1) + \frac{2}{5} E(m-1, n)$, which implies for all $E(n, 1)$, $E(n, 1) = \frac{2^{n+1}}{5^{n+1}} + \frac{2^{n-1}}{5^{n}} + \frac{2}{5} E(n-1, 1)$, or in other words

\[ \frac{5^n}{2^n} E(n, 1) = \frac{9}{10} + \frac{5^{n-1}}{2^{n-1}} E(n-1, 1) \]Letting $F(n) = \frac{5^n}{2^n} E(n, 1)$, with $F(0) = \frac{2}{5}$ gives a way, way simpler recursion we can solve, $F(n) = \frac{9}{10} + F(n-1)$, which is an arithmetic sequence that gives $F(19) = \frac{35}{2}$, which gives $E(19, 1) = \frac{7 \cdot 2^{18}}{5^{18}}$. Meanwhile, $E(19, 0) = \frac{2^{19}}{5^{19}}$.



The probability that the last roll is prime is then

\[ \frac{3}{5} \cdot \frac{2^{19}}{5^{19}} + \frac{3}{5} \frac{7 \cdot 2^{18}}{5^{18}} = \frac{3}{5} \cdot \frac{2^{19}}{5^{19}} \cdot \left( 1 + \frac{35}{2} \right) = \boxed{\frac{2^{18} \cdot 3 \cdot 37}{5^{20}}} \]

problems.title: 2018 C7: Light Bulbs in a Circle

Y by Adventure10By the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion, the number of ways to turn on light bulbs so that there exists four consecutive light bulbs is $$9\cdot2^5-9\cdot2^4-9\cdot2^3-9\cdot2^2-9\cdot2+9\cdot2^3+18\cdot2^2+27\cdot2+30\cdot1-9\cdot2^2-27\cdot2-90\cdot1+9\cdot2+117\cdot1-84\cdot1+36\cdot1-9\cdot1+1\cdot1,$$which evaluates to $145$. Hence our answer is $512-145=367$.

problems.title: 2018 C9: Rearrangements of Sequence
problems.text: Compute the number of rearrangements $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_{2018}$ of the sequence $1, 2, \dots, 2018$ such that $a_k > k$ for $\textit{exactly}$ one value of $k$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247What a neat problem! One key lemma is the following:



Claim 1: The number of permutations $\pi$ of $[n]$ with $\pi(1) = n$, and $\pi(i) \leq i$ for $i = 2,3,\ldots, n$ is $2^{n-2}$.



Proof: We have 2 choices for $\pi(2)$, and then 2 choices for $\pi(3)$, and so on, but we only have 1 choice for $\pi(n)$. $\Box$



Now, suppose that we have $a_k = m > k$. Then, notice that if $m \neq 2018$, then $a_{2018} = 2018$. Then, if $m\neq 2017$, $a_{2017} = 2017$. Working our way down, we see that $a_{m+1} = m+1, a_{m+2} = m+2, \ldots$. Also, $a_1 = 1, a_2 = 2$, until $a_{k-1} = k-1$. On the other hand, by our Lemma, there are actually $2^{m-k-1}$ ways to assign $a_{k+1}, \ldots, a_m$ (simply by shifting so that $k = 1$)



So, we want \[
\frac 12\sum_{1\leq k < m \leq 2018} 2^{m-k} = \frac 12\sum_{1\leq d\leq 2017} (2018-d)2^d = \frac 12 (2^{2019} - 4038) = \boxed{2^{2018}-2019}.
\]

problems.title: 2025 Combo/CS Problem 1
problems.text: Robert has five beads in his hand, with the letters $C, M, I, M,$ and $C,$ and he wants to make a circular bracelet spelling "$CMIMC.$" However, the power went out, so Robert can no longer see the beads in his hand. Thus, he puts the five beads on the bracelet randomly, hoping that the bracelet, when possibly rotated or flipped, spells out "$CMIMC.$" What is the probability that this happens? (Robert doesn’t care whether some letters appear upside down or backwards.)
problems.solution:
To take care of the rotation condition, we fix the $I$ in place. Then, let us consider the other four beads as all distinct.



The total number of ways to permute the beads on the necklace is

\begin{align*}
\frac{4!}{2} &= \frac{24}{2} \\
&= 12,
\end{align*}where we divide by $2$ to take care of the reflection condition. Then, the number of desired configurations is

\begin{align*}
\frac{2^2}{2} &= \frac{4}{2} \\
&= 2
\end{align*}because there are $2$ ways to choose which $C$ bead goes where and $2$ ways to choose which $M$ bead goes where, and then we divide by $2$ to account for the reflection condition.



Hence, the answer is $$\frac{2}{12} = \boxed{\frac{1}{6}}.$$$\square$

problems.title: 2025 Alg/NT Problem 2
problems.text: I plotted the graphs $y=(x-0)^2, y=(x-5)^2, \ldots, y=(x-45)^2.$ I also draw a line $y=k,$ and notice that it intersects the parabolas at exactly $19$ distinct points. What is $k$?
problems.solution:
Since each of the parabolas can intersect the line $y=k$ in at most two points, it follows that the maximum total number of distinct intersection points is $20.$ Therefore, there will be exactly $19$ distinct intersection points when $y=k',$ where $k'$ is the largest real number such that two of the parabolas intersect at a point with $y$-coordinate $k'.$ This clearly occurs when the parabolas $y=(x-0)^2$ and $y=(x-45)^2$ intersect. We have

\begin{align*}
(x-0)^2=(x-45)^2 &\implies x^2=x^2-90x+2025 \\
&\implies 90x=2025 \\
&\implies x = \frac{45}{2},
\end{align*}so the $y$-coordinate of their intersection point is $$\left(\frac{45}{2}\right)^2=\boxed{\frac{2025}{4}}.$$$\square$

problems.title: 2025 Alg/NT Problem 3
problems.text: Compute $3^{3^{\ldots^3}} \mod{333},$ where there are $3^{3^3}$ $3$'s in the exponent.
problems.solution:
Let $N_i$ denote $3^{3^{\ldots^3}},$ where there are $i$ $3$'s in the exponent. We wish to compute $N_{3^{3^3}}$ modulo $333.$ It suffices to compute $N_{3^{3^3}}$ modulo $9$ and $37$ and then the Chinese Remainder Theorem will finish.



First of all, since $N_{3^{3^3}-1} \ge 2,$ it follows that $N_{3^{3^3}} \equiv 0 \pmod{9}.$



Then, we know that $N_{3^{3^3}-1} \equiv 0 \pmod{9}$ since $N_{3^{3^3}-2} \ge 2.$ Also, since $N_{3^{3^3}-2}$ is obviously odd, it follows that $$N_{3^{3^3}-1} \equiv 3 \pmod{4},$$so the Chinese Remainder Theorem yields $$N_{3^{3^3}-1} \equiv 27 \pmod{36}.$$Hence, by Fermat's Little Theorem, we have

\begin{align*}
N_{3^{3^3}} &= 3^{N_{3^{3^3}-1}} \\
&\equiv 3^{27} \\
&\equiv 27^9 \\
&\equiv (-10)^9 \\
&\equiv (-1000)^3 \\
&\equiv (-1)^3 \\
&\equiv -1 \\
&\equiv 36 \pmod{37}.
\end{align*}Therefore, we have the system of congruences: $$\begin{cases}
N_{3^{3^3}} \equiv 0 \pmod{9}, \\
N_{3^{3^3}} \equiv 36 \pmod{37}.
\end{cases}$$Hence, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, the answer is $$N_{3^{3^3}} \equiv \boxed{36} \pmod{333}.$$$\square$

problems.title: 2025 Alg/NT Problem 4
problems.text: Consider the system of equations $$\log_x y +\log_y z + \log_z x =8$$$$\log_{\log_y x}z = -3$$$$\log_z y + \log_x z = 16$$Find $z.$
problems.solution:
Manipulating the third equation yields

\begin{align*}
\log_z y + \log_x z = 16 &\implies \frac{1}{\log_y z} + \frac{1}{\log_z x} = 16 \\
&\implies \frac{\log_y z + \log_z x}{\log_y z \cdot \log_z x} = 16 \\
&\implies \frac{\log_yz+\log_zx}{\log_y x} = 16 \\
&\implies \log_yz+\log_zx = 16\log_y x.
\end{align*}Now, let $\log_y x = t.$ If we plug in $16\log_y x$ for $\log_yz+\log_zx$ in the first equation and then substitute $t$ for $\log_y x,$ then we get

\begin{align*}
\log_x y +\log_y z + \log_z x =8 &\implies \log_x y + 16\log_y x = 8 \\
&\implies 16t+\frac{1}{t} = 8 \\
&\implies 16t^2-8t+1=0 \\
&\implies (4t-1)^2=0 \\
&\implies 4t=1 \\
&\implies t = \frac{1}{4}.
\end{align*}Hence, the answer is

\begin{align*}
z &= \left(\log_y x\right)^{-3} \\
&=t^{-3} \\
&= \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{-3} \\
&= \boxed{64}.
\end{align*}$\square$

problems.title: 2025 Geo Problem 1
problems.text: I’m given a square of side length $7,$ and I want to make a regular tetrahedron from it. Specifically, my strategy is to cut out a net. If I cut out a parallelogram-shaped net that yields the biggest regular tetrahedron, what is the surface area of the resulting tetrahedron?
problems.solution:
First of all, the surface area of the resulting tetrahedron is just the area of the net. Therefore, we wish to maximize the area of the net.



It is not difficult to see that the net's area is maximized when its longer diagonal coincides with one of the diagonals of the square. In this case, the longer diagonal of the net will be $7\sqrt{2},$ so the side length of each of the equilateral triangles making up the net will be $\sqrt{14}.$ Therefore, the base and height of the net will be $2\sqrt{14}$ and $\tfrac{\sqrt{42}}{2},$ respectively, yielding an answer of $$2\sqrt{14} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{42}}{3} = \boxed{14\sqrt{3}}.$$$\square$

problems.title: 2025 Team Problem 5
problems.text: Suppose we have a uniformly random function from $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 25\}$ to itself. Find the expected value of $$\sum_{x=1}^{25} (f(f(x))-x)^2.$$
problems.solution:
Firstly, note that

\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} (f(f(x))-x)^2\right] &= \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} (f(f(x))^2-2f(f(x))x+x^2)\right] \\
&= \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} f(f(x))^2\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25}2f(f(x))x\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25}x^2 \right] \\
&= \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} f(f(x))^2\right] - 2\sum_{x=1}^{25}\mathbb{E}\left[f(f(x))x\right] +\sum_{x=1}^{25}x^2 \\
&=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} f(f(x))^2\right] - 2\sum_{x=1}^{25} x\mathbb{E}[f(f(x))] + 5525.
\end{align*}By symmetry, we have

\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} f(f(x))^2 \right] &= \sum_{x=1}^{25} x^2 \\
&= 5525.
\end{align*}Also, note that $f(f(x))=x$ if and only if either $f(x)=x$ or $f(x)=y \neq x$ and $f(y)=x.$ The former occurs with probability $\tfrac{1}{25},$ and the latter occurs with probability $\tfrac{24}{25} \cdot \tfrac{1}{25},$ for a total of

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{25} + \frac{24}{25} \cdot \frac{1}{25} &= \frac{1}{25} + \frac{24}{625} \\
&= \frac{49}{625}.
\end{align*}If $f(f(x)) \neq x,$ then it is equally likely to be any element from the set $\{1, \ldots, 25\} \setminus \{x\},$ so it follows that

\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}[f(f(x))] &= \frac{49}{625} \cdot x + \frac{576}{625} \cdot \frac{(1+\ldots+25)-x}{24} \\
&= \frac{49x}{625} + \frac{24}{625} \cdot 325 - \frac{24x}{625} \\
&= \frac{x}{25} + \frac{312}{25}.
\end{align*}Therefore, we get

\begin{align*}
2\sum_{x=1}^{25} x\mathbb{E}[f(f(x))] &= 2\sum_{x=1}^{25} \left(\frac{x^2}{25} + \frac{312x}{25}\right) \\
&= \frac{2}{25} \cdot 5525 + \frac{624}{25} \cdot 325 \\
&= 8554,
\end{align*}yielding an answer of

\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{x=1}^{25} f(f(x))^2\right] - 2\sum_{x=1}^{25} x\mathbb{E}[f(f(x))] + 5525 &= 5525-8554+5525 \\
&= \boxed{2496}.
\end{align*}$\square$

problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionNote that $\angle ADE =\angle AED$ so triangle $\triangle ADE$ is isosceles. Let $AD=AE=s$. problems.title: 2017 G3: Two Differences Determine Another Difference
problems.text: In acute triangle $ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ are the feet of the angle bisector and altitude from $A$ respectively.  Suppose that $AC - AB = 36$ and $DC - DB = 24$.  Compute $EC - EB$.
problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionLet $AB=x$ and $DB = y$. We know that $AC =x+36$ and $DC=y+24$. From the Angle Bisector Theorem, $\frac{x+36}{x}=\frac{y+24}{y}$. This can be rewritten as $\frac{x}{y}=\frac{3}{2}$ or $\frac{3y}{2}=x$. Note that from Pythagorean Theorem, $AE^2=AC^2-EC^2=AB^2-EB^2$. This means that $AC^2-AB^2=EC^2-EB^2$. Using the difference of squares factorization, $$(AC-AB)(AC+AB)=(EC-EB)(EC+EB)$$$$36\cdot (3y+36) = (EC-EB)\cdot (2y+24)$$$$36\cdot \frac{3}{2}=EC-EB$$,which means $\boxed{54}$ is our answer.

problems.title: 2017 G4: Hey Look, Coordinates!
problems.text: Let $\mathcal S$ be the sphere with center $(0,0,1)$ and radius $1$ in $\mathbb R^3$.  A plane $\mathcal P$ is tangent to $\mathcal S$ at the point $(x_0,y_0,z_0)$, where $x_0$, $y_0$, and $z_0$ are all positive.  Suppose the intersection of plane $\mathcal P$ with the $xy$-plane is the line with equation $2x+y=10$ in $xy$-space.  What is $z_0$?
problems.solution:
Y by Phoenix_The_Cat, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe see that the plane is the locus of all points $(x,y,z)$ such that the vectors $\langle x-x_0,y-y_0,z-z_0\rangle$ and $\langle x_0,y_0,z_0-1\rangle $ are orthogonal.



This gives us the equation of the plane as, by dot product, $x_0(x-x_0)+y_0(y-y_0)+(z-z_0)(z_0-1) = 0$. Intersecting this with $z=0$ gives $x_0x+y_0y = x_0^2+y_0^2 + z_0^2 -z_0$.



But $x_0^2+y_0^2 + (z_0-1)^2 = 1$, so this gives us $x_0^2+y_0^2+z_0^2 -z_0 = z_0$. So, $x_0x+y_0y = z_0$. So, $z_0 = 10y_0, x_0 = 2y_0$, and so since $x_0^2 + y_0^2 + z_0^2  = 2z_0$, we get $105y_0^2 = 20y_0$, or $y_0 = \frac{4}{21}$. This gives us $z _0 = \boxed{\frac{40}{21}}$.

problems.title: 2017 G7: Bisection of Segment
problems.text: Two non-intersecting circles, $\omega$ and $\Omega$, have centers $C_\omega$ and $C_\Omega$ respectively.  It is given that the radius of $\Omega$ is strictly larger than the radius of $\omega$.  The two common external tangents of $\Omega$ and $\omega$ intersect at a point $P$, and an internal tangent of the two circles intersects the common external tangents at $X$ and $Y$.  Suppose that the radius of $\omega$ is $4$, the circumradius of $\triangle PXY$ is $9$, and $XY$ bisects $\overline{PC_\Omega}$.  Compute $XY$.
problems.solution:
Y by Einstein314, Adventure10solThe problem is equivalent to finding $BC$ in a triangle $ABC$ in which the $A$-altitude is of the same length as $r_a$, the $A$-exradius.

Denote by $R = 9$ and $r = 4$ the circumradius and inradius of $ABC$, respectively, and let $M$ be the midpoint of minor arc $BC$.

From $r_a = h_a$, we easily obtain $2a = b + c$.



By a well-known lemma, if $2a = b + c$, then $I$ is the midpoint of $AM$.

Hence, $OI$ is a perpendicular bisector of $AM$.

Euler's theorem gives $OI = \sqrt{R(R - 2r)} = \sqrt{9(9 - 8)} = 3$, so by Pythagoras, $AI = 6\sqrt{2}$.



Finally, $\sin \left( \frac{A}{2} \right) = \frac{r}{AI} = \frac{2}{3\sqrt{2}}$, so $\cos \left( \frac{A}{2} \right) = \frac{\sqrt{14}}{3\sqrt{2}}$.

Then $\sin(A) = 2\cos \left( \frac{A}{2} \right) \sin \left( \frac{A}{2} \right) = \frac{2\sqrt{14}}{9}$, so by Law of Sines, $a = 2R\sin(A) = 4\sqrt{14}$.

problems.title: 2017 G10: Parallel Euler Lines
problems.text: Suppose $\triangle ABC$ is such that $AB=13$, $AC=15$, and $BC=14$.  It is given that there exists a unique point $D$ on side $\overline{BC}$ such that the Euler lines of $\triangle ABD$ and $\triangle ACD$ are parallel.  Determine the value of $\tfrac{BD}{CD}$.  (The $\textit{Euler}$ line of a triangle $ABC$ is the line connecting the centroid, circumcenter, and orthocenter of $ABC$.)
problems.solution:
Y by Math1331Math, dchen, Adventure10, Mango247CoordinatesWe will be doing investigation on the centroids and circumcenters of both triangles. Let $B$ be $(0,0)$, $A$ be $(5,12)$, $C$ be $(14,0)$, and $D$ be $(x,0)$. We're trying to find $x$.

Note that $G_{ABD}=(\frac{x+5}{3},4)$ and $G_{ACD}=(\frac{x+19}{3},4)$.

Now let $O_{ABC}=(\frac{x}{2},y_1)$. Get the equation $(\frac{x}{2}-0)^2+(y_1-0)^2=(\frac{x}{2}-5)^2+(y_1-12)^2$. So $y_1=\frac{169-5x}{24}$.

Now let $O_{ABD}=(\frac{x+14}{2},y_2)$. Get the equation $(\frac{x+14}{2}-x)^2+(y_2-0)^2=(\frac{x+14}{2}-5)^2+(y_2-12)^2$. So $y_2=\frac{9x+99}{24}$.

Set the slopes of the Euler lines equal to one another. So we have $\frac{\frac{169-5x}{24}-4}{\frac{x}{2}-\frac{x+5}{3}}=\frac{\frac{9x+99}{24}-4}{\frac{x+14}{2}-\frac{x+19}{3}}$. This becomes the equation $x^2-10x-23=0$, and we want the positive root which is $x=5+4\sqrt{3}$.

So $BD=5+4\sqrt{3}$ and $CD=9-4\sqrt{3}$. Therefore $\frac{BD}{CD}=\boxed{\frac{93+56\sqrt{3}}{33}}$.

problems.title: 2017 C1: Coloring of Squares
problems.text: Robert colors each square in an empty 3 by 3 grid either red or green. Find the number of colorings such that no row or column contains more than one green square.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionNote that we can only have up to $3$ green squares, and from here, we will proceed with casework.



Case 1: 0 green squares



Obviously, only one coloring here.



Case 2: 1 green square



This can be done in $\dbinom{3}{1} \cdot \dbinom{3}{1} = 9$ ways (pick a row, then pick a column, which determines where our square lies).



Case 3: 2 green squares



There are $\dbinom{3}{2} \cdot \dbinom{3}{2} \cdot 2 = 18$ colorings here (pick 2 rows, pick 2 columns, then multiply by two since there are two ways to pair the rows and columns up).



Case 4: 3 green squares



Here, we must simply count how many ways there are to pair up rows with columns. If the rows are $A, B, C$, and the columns are $1, 2, 3$, then this is simply the number of ways to arrange $1, 2, 3$ (since any arrangement uniquely determines which row is with which column), which is $3! =  6$.



Adding up our cases, there are $1 + 9 + 18 + 6 = \boxed{34}$ total colorings.

problems.title: 2017 C2: Avoiding 7
problems.text: Let $S$ be a subset of $\{1,2,\dots,2017\}$ such that for any two distinct elements in $S$, both their sum and product are not divisible by seven. Compute the maximum number of elements that can be in $S$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThe only time we get a "bad product" is when at least one of the two elements is divisible by 7. Thus, we must eliminate all numbers that are congruent to $0 \pmod 7$, eliminating $288$ numbers.



Also, if we add "bad residue classes together", i.e. we add $a$ and $b$, such that if $a \equiv n \pmod 7$, then $b \equiv 7 - n \pmod 7$, the sum will be divisible by $7$. Thus, we can simply eliminate one "bad class" from each pair, $(1, 6), (2, 5), (3, 4)$, so that the pairwise sum is never divisible by $7$. Note that aside from the residue class $n \equiv 1 \pmod 7$, which has $289$ elements, each of the remaining 6 residue classes has $288$ elements. Since we want to minimize the number of elements we remove, we can remove three of the residue classes with $288$ elements, thus removing $3 \cdot 288$ more elements.



Finally, our answer is $2017 - 288 - 3 \cdot 288 = \boxed{865}$.

problems.title: 2017 C3: Annie and a Hexagon
problems.text: Annie stands at one vertex of a regular hexagon. Every second, she moves independently to one of the two vertices adjacent to her, each with equal probability. Determine the probability that she is at her starting position after ten seconds.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionLet a move in the clockwise direction be noted as +1 and a move in the counterclockwise direction be denoted as -1. The original vertex can be reached by a sequence of 10 moves summing to either 0, 6, -6, 12, -12, etc. where the sum is congruent to 0 mod 6. The only such sums reachable in 10 moves are 0, 6, and -6.



In the case where the sum is 0:

5 +1 moves and 5 -1 moves have been chosen in the 10 moves. There are $\binom{10}{5} = 252$ such series of moves.



In the case where the sum is 6:

8 +1 moves and 2 -1 moves have been chosen in the 10 moves. There are $\binom{10}{2} = 45$ such series of moves.



In the case where the sum is -6:

2 +1 moves and 8 -1 moves have been chosen in the 10 moves. There are $\binom{10}{8} = 45$ such series of moves.



Thus, the total number of series of 10 +1 or -1 moves that sum to some number congruent to 0 mod 6 is $342$. The total number of series of 10 moves is $2^{10} = 1024$. Thus, our final answer is $\frac{342}{1024} = \boxed{\frac{171}{512}}$.

problems.title: 2017 C5: Red-triangle-free Colorings
problems.text: Emily draws six dots on a piece of paper such that no three lie on a straight line, then draws a line segment connecting each pair of dots. She then colors five of these segments red. Her coloring is said to be $\emph{red-triangle-free}$ if for every set of three points from her six drawn points there exists an uncolored segment connecting two of the three points. In how many ways can Emily color her drawing such that it is red-triangle-free?
problems.solution:
Y by Williamgolly, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe note that there are $\binom{6}{2} = 15$ segments in her diagram. There are $\binom{15}{5} = 3003$ ways to choose 5 of these segments to color red.



We then try to find the number of ways she can color 5 segments so that there is at least one triangle. There are $\binom{6}{3} = 20$ ways to choose a triangle from these 6 vertices. Thus, there are $20 \binom{12}{2}$ ways to choose 5 segments so that they form at least one red triangle. However, we have overcounted the number of ways when 2 triangles are formed. There are $20$ ways to select the first triangle and then $3$ ways to select a fourth point followed by $3$ ways to select the common edge. Dividing by 2 yields that there are $90$ such ways to choose two triangles.



Thus, we get our final answer of $3003 - 1320 + 90 = \boxed{1773}$.

problems.text:

problems.title: 2017 C8: Finite Random Sequence
problems.text:
Andrew generates a finite random sequence $\{a_n\}$ of distinct integers according to the following criteria:

$a_0 = 1$, $0 < |a_n| < 7$ for all $n$, and $a_i \neq a_j$ for all $i < j$.
$a_{n+1}$ is selected uniformly at random from the set $\{a_n - 1, a_n + 1, -a_n\}$, conditioned on the above rule. The sequence terminates if no element of the set satisfies the first condition.

For example, if $(a_0, a_1) = (1, 2)$, then $a_2$ would be chosen from the set $\{-2,3\}$, each with probability $\tfrac12$. Determine the probability that there exists an integer $k$ such that $a_k = 6$.

problems.title: 2017 C9: Conference Badges
problems.text: At a conference, six people place their name badges in a hat, which is shaken up; one badge is then distributed to each person such that each distribution is equally likely. Each turn, every person who does not yet have their own badge finds the person whose badge they have and takes that person's badge. For example, if Alice has Bob's badge and Bob has Charlie's badge, Alice would have Charlie's badge after a turn. Compute the probability that everyone will eventually end up with their own badge.
problems.solution:
Y by Math1331Math, speck, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe start with a permutation $\pi: [6] \to [6]$. Decomposing $\pi$ by cycles, we see that each turn the cycles change as follows: an even cycle $a_1 \to a_2 \to \ldots \to a_{2n} \to a_1$ gets broken up into two cycles $a_1 \to a_3 \to \ldots \to a_{2n-1} \to a_1$ and $a_2 \to a_4 \to \ldots \to a_{2n} \to a_2$, and an odd cycle $a_1 \to a_2 \to \ldots \to a_{2n+1} \to a_1$ gets shifted as $a_1 \to a_3 \to \ldots a_{2n+1} \to a_2 \to a_4 \ldots a_{2n} \to a_1$. Crucially, at each turn, an even cycle gets broken up into two cycles of the same (half the original) length, while odd cycles do not change in length.



Thus, eventually, all cycles will have odd length; for the process to end, we need all these cycles to be length $1$, so the cycles of the original permutation $\pi$ must all have length a power of two. We take cases on the complement, which is easier to count:

Case 1: there is a cycle of length $3$. There are $2 \tbinom{6}{3} = 40$ possible cycles, and then $3! = 6$ ways to arrange the remaining three elements, for $40 \cdot 6 = 240$ permutations total. But this double-counts permutations with two $3$-cycles: there are $2^2 \cdot \tfrac12\tbinom{6}{3} = 40$ such permutations, so we have $240 - 40 = 200$ permutations with at least one $3$-cycle.
Case 2: there is a cycle of length $5$. There are $6$ ways to choose the loner, which maps to itself, and then $4! = 24$ ways to choose the order of the $5$-cycle. Thus we have $6 \cdot 24 = 144$ permutations with a $5$-cycle.
Case 3: there is a cycle of length $6$. There are $5! = 120$ such permutations.

Thus we have $200 + 144 + 120 = 464$ permutations which violate the condition, and thus $6! - 464 = 720 - 464 = 256$ permutations that work, for a probability of $\tfrac{256}{720} = \tfrac{16}{45}$.

problems.title: 2017 NT2: Difference Between GCD and LCM
problems.text: Determine all possible values of $m+n$, where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers satisfying \[\operatorname{lcm}(m,n) - \gcd(m,n) = 103.\]
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionLet $m=dm'$ and $n=dn'$ where $\gcd(m,n)=d$. We know that $m\cdot n =\gcd(m,n)\cdot lcm(m,n) \implies lcm(m,n)=dm'n'$. Plugging these in, $dm'n'-d=d(m'n'-1)=103$. This means either $d=103$ or $d=1$.



Case 1: $d=103$



This would mean $m'n'=2$ where $m',n'$ are relatively prime. Clearly $(2,1)$ and $(1,2)$ are the only solutions but order doesn't matter. So one value for $m+n=103(1+2)=309$.



Case 2: $d=1$



This would mean $m'n'=104$ for relatively prime $m',n'$. The only ways for this to occur are $(104,1),(1,104),(13,8),(8,13)$ but again order doesn't matter. So we have $1(104+1)=105$ and $1(8+13)=21$ from this case.



Our answer is $\boxed{21,105,309}$.

problems.title: 2017 NT5: Rational GCD
problems.text: One can define the greatest common divisor of two positive rational numbers as follows: for $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ positive integers with $\gcd(a,b)=\gcd(c,d)=1$, write \[\gcd\left(\dfrac ab,\dfrac cd\right) = \dfrac{\gcd(ad,bc)}{bd}.\]For all positive integers $K$, let $f(K)$ denote the number of ordered pairs of positive rational numbers $(m,n)$ with $m<1$ and $n<1$ such that \[\gcd(m,n)=\dfrac{1}{K}.\]What is $f(2017)-f(2016)$?
problems.solution: It suffices to find rational numbers $M,N <K$ such that $\gcd(M,N) = 1$ since $\gcd\left( \frac{M}{K} , \frac{N}{K} \right) = \frac{1}{K}$. If $M = \frac{a}{b}$ and $N = \frac{c}{d}$ then we have $bd = \gcd(ad,bc)$ so $b \mid a$ and $d \mid c$. Hence, $M$ and $N$ are integers so $f(K)$ is equal to the number of pairs of positive integers $1 \le M,N < K$ such that $\gcd(M,N) = 1$. We wish to find $f(2017) - f(2016)$ which is simply $2$ times the number of positive integers, $N$, less than $2016$ such that $\gcd(2016,N) = 1$. This is simply $2 \varphi(2016) = \boxed{1152}$.

problems.title: 2017 NT8: Sum of Squares Divisible by 2017
problems.text: Let $N$ be the number of ordered triples $(a,b,c) \in \{1, \ldots, 2016\}^{3}$ such that $a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} \equiv 0 \pmod{2017}$. What are the last three digits of $N$?
problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SketchMuch easier is to consider the equation $x^2+y^2\equiv -1\pmod{2017}$. It is well known that $2017$ is prime. The number of $(x,y)$ satisfying the prior equivalence is $S=\frac{1}{4}\sum_{k=1}^{2016} \left(1+\left(\tfrac{k}{2017}\right)\right)\left(1+\left(\tfrac{-1-k}{2017}\right)\right)$, which can be evaluated by the method found here. To finish, we just take $2016S$ to account for $c$.

problems.title: 2017 NT9: Sum of Powers Diophantine
problems.text:
Find the smallest prime $p$ for which there exist positive integers $a,b$ such that

\[
		a^{2} + p^{3} = b^{4}.
	\]
problems.solution: Y by Adventure10Is this$p^3=(b^2-a)(b^2+a)$. Clearly $p=2$ is a bust. Then the $\gcd$ between the two factors is $g=\gcd(a,b^2)$. Suppose first that $g=p\implies pb'^2-a'=1,\ pb'^2+a'=p$, the latter of which is clearly impossible. So we must have $b^2-1=a\implies 2b^2-1=p^3$. By the Second Supplement, we can confine our search to $p\equiv 1,7\pmod{8}$. Testing $p=7,17,23$ shows that $\boxed{p=23}$ is in fact a solution. correct?

problems.title: 2017 NT10: GCD of Products of Factorials
problems.text: For each positive integer $n$, define \[g(n) = \gcd\left\{0! n!, 1! (n-1)!, 2 (n-2)!, \ldots, k!(n-k)!, \ldots, n! 0!\right\}.\]Find the sum of all $n \leq 25$ for which $g(n) = g(n+1)$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Solution?Note that

\[g(n)=\prod_{\text{p prime, } p\le n} \min_{0\le a_p\le n} \left(p^{\left(\dfrac{n-s_p(a_p)-s_p(n-a_p)}{p-1}\right)}\right).\]Also, in order to maximize $s_p(a_p)+s_p(n-a_p)$, we note that we want as many carries as possible in the base-$p$ addition of $a_p+(n-a_p)$, so we want to set $a_p=p^{\lfloor\log_{p}(n)\rfloor}-1$ (note that when $n=p^b-1$ for some $b$ there can't be any carries so it doesn't matter too much what we set $a_p$ and we don't need to set $a_p=p^b-1$.). Thus, we note that, for $p\le n, n\neq p^b-1$ for some $b$, since $a_p$ is the same for $n$ and $n+1$,

\[ \min_{0\le a_p\le n} \left(p^{\left(\dfrac{n-s_p(a_p)-s_p(n-a_p)}{p-1}\right)}\right)\neq \min_{0\le a_p\le n+1} \left(p^{\left(\dfrac{n+1-s_p(a_p)-s_p(n+1-a_p)}{p-1}\right)}\right)\]if and only if there's a carry in the base-$p$ addition of $1+(n-a_p)$; that is, when $n\equiv -2\pmod{p}$ (it's also easy to check the "border case," when $n=p^b-1$ for some $b$, does not satisfy the above not-equality (idk what it's called)). Thus, we want the sum of all $n\le 25$ such that $p\nmid n+2$ for all $p\le n$, or basically when $n+2$ is prime. Listing, we get $1, 3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 17, 21$ so our sum is $\boxed{82}$.

problems.title: 2017 TB A3: Rotation of parabola
problems.text: The parabola $\mathcal P$ given by equation $y=x^2$ is rotated some acute angle $\theta$ clockwise about the origin such that it hits both the $x$ and $y$ axes at two distinct points.  Suppose the length of the segment $\mathcal P$ cuts the $x$-axis is $1$.  What is the length of the segment $\mathcal P$ cuts the $y$-axis?
problems.solution:
Y by Math1331Math, Adventure10What kind of form should the answer have to be acceptable? I got Click to reveal hidden text$\sqrt{2+\sqrt{5}}$

Edit: Yay okay then the solution is
djmathman wrote:
The parabola $\mathcal P$ given by equation $y=x^2$ is rotated some acute angle $\theta$ clockwise about the origin such that it hits both the $x$ and $y$ axes at two distinct points.  Suppose the length of the segment $\mathcal P$ cuts the $x$-axis is $1$.  What is the length of the segment $\mathcal P$ cuts the $y$-axis?

Actually, I like my $x$ and $y$ axes where they are, but I also would like to keep the parabola $y=x^2$. So I fix the $x,y-$axes+parabola and denote the results after the rotation as the orthogonal lines $u$ and $v$ who coincide at the origin. Write the second coincidence of $u$ and the parabola $y=x^2$ as the point $(\delta,\delta^2)$ for some $x$-coordinate $\delta$. By pythag we have $\delta^2(\delta^2+1)=\delta^2+\delta^4=1\implies \delta=\sqrt{\tfrac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}}$. We also have that $u(x)=\delta x$ and $v(x)=-\tfrac{1}{\delta}x$. The second intersection of the parabola and $v$ has $x^2=v(x)=-\tfrac{1}{\delta}x$, so it occurs at $(-\tfrac{1}{\delta},\tfrac{1}{\delta^2})$. Thus our desired length is $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{\delta^2}+\frac{1}{\delta^4}}=\sqrt{\frac{\delta^2+1}{\delta^4}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\delta^6}}=\frac{1}{\delta^3}=\frac{\sqrt{8}}{(-1+\sqrt{5})^3}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{-2+\sqrt{5}}}=\boxed{\sqrt{2+\sqrt{5}}}$$

The solution has the interesting property that it can not be represented as $a+b\sqrt{c},\ a,b,c\in\mathbb Q$, since its minimal polynomial, of fourth degree, is irreducible in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$.

problems.title: 2017 TB CS3: 7-CNF Clauses
problems.text: Let $n=2017$ and $x_1,\dots,x_n$ be boolean variables. An \emph{$7$-CNF clause} is an expression of the form $\phi_1(x_{i_1})+\dots+\phi_7(x_{i_7})$, where $\phi_1,\dots,\phi_7$ are each either the function $f(x)=x$ or $f(x)=1-x$, and $i_1,i_2,\dots,i_7\in\{1,2,\dots,n\}$. For example, $x_1+(1-x_1)+(1-x_3)+x_2+x_4+(1-x_3)+x_{12}$ is a $7$-CNF clause. What's the smallest number $k$ for which there exist $7$-CNF clauses $f_1,\dots,f_k$ such that \[f(x_1,\dots,x_n):=f_1(x_1,\dots,x_n)\cdots f_k(x_1,\dots,x_n)\]is $0$ for all values of $(x_1,\dots,x_n)\in\{0,1\}^n$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionIt is easy to see $k > 1$.

Now consider $f_1(x_1, ... , x_n) = x_1 + x_1 + x_1 + x_1 + x_1 + x_1 + x_1$ and $f_2(x_1, ... , x_n) = (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1) + (1 - x_1)$.

Then clearly, $f(x_1, ... , x_n) = 0$ for all values of $(x_1, ... , x_n) \in \lbrace 0,1\rbrace^n$; for example, if $x_1 = 1$, then $f_1$ and $f_2$ will evaluate to 7 and 0 respectively, and if $x_1 = 0$, then $f_1$ and $f_2$ will evaluate to 0 and 7 respectively.

Therefore the smallest number $k$ is $\boxed{2}$.

problems.title: 2017 TB G1: Maximum Area of Trapezoid
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be an isosceles trapezoid with $AD\parallel BC$.  Points $P$ and $Q$ are placed on segments $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{DA}$ respectively such that $AP\perp CD$ and $BQ\perp DA$, and point $X$ is the intersection of these two altitudes.  Suppose that $BX=3$ and $XQ=1$.  Compute the largest possible area of $ABCD$.
problems.solution:
Y by Math1331Math, dchen, Adventure10SolutionNote that $AD>BC$, otherwise we have a configuration issue. Also, since $\triangle{AQX}$~$\triangle{BQA}$, $AQ^2=QX \cdot BQ$, so $AQ=2$. Let $BC=x$. Then $AD=x+4$, and since $\triangle{APD}$~$\triangle{AQX}$, $\frac{DQ}{AD}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}$. So $DP=\frac{x+4}{\sqrt{5}}$. Also, $AB^2=2^2+4^2$, and since $DP<AB=CD$, we have $\frac{x+4}{\sqrt{5}} \le 2\sqrt{5}$. Therefore $x \le 6$, so $x=6$ to achieve maximum area.



Maximum area is therefore $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4 \cdot (6+(6+4))=32$.

problems.title: 2017 TB G2: Tangent to Incircle I
problems.text: Points $A$, $B$, and $C$ lie on a circle $\Omega$ such that $A$ and $C$ are diametrically opposite each other.  A line $\ell$ tangent to the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ at $T$ intersects $\Omega$ at points $X$ and $Y$.  Suppose that $AB=30$, $BC=40$, and $XY=48$.  Compute $TX\cdot TY$.
problems.solution:
Y by Phoenix_The_Cat, Adventure10SolutionClearly $AC = 50$; let $O$ be the centre of $\Omega$, then let $P$ be the foot from $O$ to $XY$; then, $OP = 7$. We see also that if $I$ is the incentre, and $Q$ point of tangency of the incircle with $AC$, then $AX = \frac{30+50-40}{2} = 20$. So, $OX = 5$. Also, the inradius is $\frac{30+40-50}{2} = 10$. So, $IO^2 = OX^2 + XI^2 = 125$.



However, we see that $PT^2 + (IT\pm OP)^2 = IO^2$, depending on which side of $XY$ $O$ and $I$ are on. We see that since $IT+OP = 17$, then clearly we must have $IT-OP^2$, otherwise $PT^2 <0$. So, $PT^2 = 116$. Also, since $OP^2 = 49$, we get $OT^2 = 165$, giving us $TX\cdot TY = 25^2 - OT^2 = \boxed{460}$.

problems.title: 2017 TB G3: Tangent to Incircle II
problems.text: Triangle $ABC$ satisfies $AB=104$, $BC=112$, and $CA=120$.  Let $\omega$ and $\omega_A$ denote the incircle and $A$-excircle of $\triangle ABC$, respectively.  There exists a unique circle $\Omega$ passing through $A$ which is internally tangent to $\omega$ and externally tangent to $\omega_A$.  Compute the radius of $\Omega$.
problems.solution:
Y by dchen, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionDefine $I$, $E_A$, and $O$ as: Incenter, $A$-excenter, and center of $\Omega$. We want to find $r$, or the radius of $\Omega$.

Ok first off scale down to $13$-$14$-$15$ triangle.

You can use coordinate stuff to get $AI=\sqrt{65}$ and $IE_A=2\sqrt{65}$. You can also use coordinate stuff to get inradius and exradius as $4$ and $12$, respectively. So $OE_A=r+12$, $OA=r$, and $OI=r-4$.

The rest is just Stewart's theorem. You get $\sqrt{65} \cdot 2\sqrt{65} \cdot 3\sqrt{65}+3\sqrt{65} \cdot (r-4)^2=\sqrt{65} \cdot (r+12)^2+2\sqrt{65} \cdot r^2$. Solving for $r$ we get $r=\frac{49}{8}$. Now scale back up to get the answer as $\boxed{49}$.

problems.title: 2017 TB N1: Tau Equation
problems.text: Let $\tau(n)$ denote the number of positive integer divisors of $n$. For example, $\tau(4) = 3$. Find the sum of all positive integers $n$ such that $2 \tau(n) = n$.
problems.solution:
Y by dchen, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionFirst of all, I claim that $n$ cannot be a perfect square. If $n$ was an odd perfect square, since $2 \tau n$ cannot be odd so we have contradiction. If $n$ was an even perfect square, $n$ is divisible by $4$, and since $\tau n$ is odd, $2 \tau n$ is not divisible by $4$ so we have contradiction.

Since $n$ is not a perfect square, $\tau n$ is even. Also, $n$ is an even number. Therefore the factors of $n$ will come in pairs. Thus, we are guaranteed that $1$, $2$, $\frac{n}{2}$, and $n$ are factors. Therefore, we are guaranteed that $\frac{\tau n}{2}$, or $\frac{n}{4}$ factors will be less than or $\sqrt{n}$. Therefore, $\frac{n}{4} \le \sqrt{n}$.

So we check all $n$ in the range $1 \le n \le 16$. Only $n=8$ and $n=12$ work. Answer is $20$.

problems.title: 2017 T5: A Computer Science Problem?
problems.text:
We have four registers, $R_1,R_2,R_3,R_4$, such that $R_i$ initially contains the number $i$ for $1\le i\le4$. We are allowed two operations:


Simultaneously swap the contents of $R_1$ and $R_3$ as well as $R_2$ and $R_4$.


Simultaneously transfer the contents of $R_2$ to $R_3$, the contents of $R_3$ to $R_4$, and the contents of $R_4$ to $R_2$. (For example if we do this once then $(R_1,R_2,R_3,R_4)=(1,4,2,3)$.)



Using these two operations as many times as desired and in whatever order, what is the total number of possible outcomes?
problems.solution: It is easy to see that it is possible for any of $1,2,3,$ or $4$ to be the first element of some arbitrary achievable permutation. Furthermore, whenever $1,2,3,$ or $4$ is the first element, it is not difficult to see that the remaining elements must be in the order $234, 431, 124,$ and $321$ respectively (up to cycling). This excludes exactly half of the $4!=24$ possible permutations of the string $1234,$ so the answer is $$\frac{1}{2} \cdot 24 = \boxed{12}.$$$\square$

problems.title: 2017 T9: Many Tangent Circles
problems.text: Circles $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ are externally tangent to each other.  Circle $\Omega$ is placed such that $\omega_1$ is internally tangent to $\Omega$ at $X$ while $\omega_2$ is internally tangent to $\Omega$ at $Y$.  Line $\ell$ is tangent to $\omega_1$ at $P$ and $\omega_2$ at $Q$ and furthermore intersects $\Omega$ at points $A$ and $B$ with $AP<AQ$.  Suppose that $AP=2$, $PQ=4$, and $QB=3$.  Compute the length of line segment $\overline{XY}$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10SketchBy homothety $XP\cap YQ=M$ where $M$ is the midpoint of minor arc $AB$.  By $\angle QBM=\angle BYM$ we find $BQM\sim YBM$ and doing symmetric things we get \[MQ\cdot MY=MB^2=MA^2=MP\cdot MX\]so $XPQY$ is cyclic.  If we let $Z$ be the tangency point of $\omega_1,\omega_2$ and let $MZ$ meet $\Omega$ again at $C$, by Thebault's theorem we find that $Z$ is the incenter of $CAB$ and thus $MA=MZ=MB$.  Let $R=CM\cap AB$, and because radical axes bisect common external tangents we know that $MR$ is the median in $MPQ$ (and the symmedian in $MXY$).



This is enough info to solve for the lengths- notice that $XY$ is $4r$ where $r$ is the ratio of similitude from $XYM$ to $QPM$, and we can use Stewart's theorem on $ABM$ as well as PoP on $P,Q$ to finish (answer is Click to reveal hidden text$\frac{24}{\sqrt{11}}$)

problems.title: 2017 A3: Quadratic Polynomial Equation
problems.text: Suppose $P(x)$ is a quadratic polynomial with integer coefficients satisfying the identity \[P(P(x)) - P(x)^2 = x^2+x+2016\]for all real $x$.  What is $P(1)$?
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionLet $P(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$. Then we have:



$a(ax^2 + bx + c)^2 + b(ax^2 + bx + c) + c - (ax^2 + bx + c)^2 = (a-1)(ax^2 + bx + c)^2 + b(ax^2 + bx + c) + c = x^2 + x + 2016$.



Comparing the left and right hand side, this implies that the $x^4$ coefficient on the left hand side is zero. Thus,



$(a-1)(a^2) = 0 \implies a = 1$.



Substituting this into the above yields:



$b(x^2 + bx + c) + c = x^2 + x + 2016$



Comparing coefficients, we can also conclude that $b = 1$, which gives us



$x^2 + x + 2c = x^2 + x + 2016$.



Thus, we have that $2c = 2016 \implies c = 1008$.



Finally, $P(x) = x^2 + x + 1008$, so $P(1) = \boxed{1010}$.

problems.title: 2017 A5: Solution Set to Floor Equation
problems.text:
The set $S$ of positive real numbers $x$ such that

\[ \left\lfloor\frac{2x}{5}\right\rfloor + \left\lfloor\frac{3x}{5}\right\rfloor + 1 = \left\lfloor x\right\rfloor \]can be written as $S = \bigcup_{j = 1}^{\infty} I_{j}$, where the $I_{i}$ are disjoint intervals of the form $[a_{i}, b_{i}) = \{x \, | \, a_i \leq x < b_i\}$ and $b_{i} \leq a_{i+1}$ for all $i \geq 1$. Find $\sum_{i=1}^{2017} (b_{i} - a_{i})$.
problems.solution:
Y by Math1331Math, Zorger74, Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThe equation is equivalent to \[\lfloor x \rfloor - \left \lfloor \frac{2x}{5} \right\rfloor - \left\lfloor \frac{3x}{5} \right\rfloor = 1.\]The left side can only change its value when $x$ passes through an integer, an integer multiple of $\frac{5}{2}$, or an integer multiple of $\frac{5}{3}$. Furthermore, note that if we write $x = 5n + r$, $n \in \mathbb{Z}$, $0 \le r < 5$, then $\lfloor x \rfloor - \left \lfloor \frac{2x}{5} \right\rfloor - \left\lfloor \frac{3x}{5} \right\rfloor = \lfloor r \rfloor - \left \lfloor \frac{2r}{5} \right\rfloor - \left\lfloor \frac{3r}{5} \right\rfloor$. Thus it suffices to check the behavior of the left side on $0 \le x < 5$, knowing that it will repeat afterwards.



The left side begins equaling $0$ when $x = 0$, and may change value as $x$ increases past $1, \frac{5}{3}, 2, \frac{5}{2}, 3, \frac{10}{3}, 4$, and $5$. Checking each of these values, we find that $I_1 = \left[1, \frac{5}{3}\right)$, $I_2 = \left[2, \frac{5}{2}\right)$, $I_3 = \left[3, \frac{10}{3}\right)$, and $I_4 = [4, 5)$. More generally, we have that \[b_i - a_i = \begin{cases} \frac{2}{3} \qquad i \equiv 1 \pmod{4} \\ \frac{1}{2} \qquad i \equiv 2 \pmod{4} \\ \frac{1}{3} \qquad i \equiv 3 \pmod{4} \\ 1 \qquad i \equiv 0 \pmod{4} \end{cases}\]

Thus we have $\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{2017}(b_i - a_i) = \frac{2016}{4}\left(\frac{2}{3} + \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{3} + 1\right) + \frac{2}{3} = 504 \cdot \frac{5}{2} + \frac{2}{3} = 1260 + \frac{2}{3} = \boxed{\frac{3782}{3}}$.

problems.title: 2017 A6: Maximization of Quintic

problems.solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247Let the roots be $-1, a, a*, b, b*$. We are given $P$ is of the form $2(x+1)(x-a)(x-a*)(x-b)(x-b*)$. $x = 1$ yields $(2-a-a*)(2-b-b*) = 0.75$. We want to minimize $6(5-2a-2a*)(5-2b-2b*)$. Since $2-a-a* > 0$, then the minimal value occurs when $2-a-a*=2-b-b*=\sqrt{3}/2$, giving $24+12\sqrt{3}$.

problems.title: 2017 A7: Complicated System of Equations
problems.text: Let $a$, $b$, and $c$ be complex numbers satisfying the system of equations \begin{align*}\dfrac{a}{b+c}+\dfrac{b}{c+a}+\dfrac{c}{a+b}&=9,\\\dfrac{a^2}{b+c}+\dfrac{b^2}{c+a}+\dfrac{c^2}{a+b}&=32,\\\dfrac{a^3}{b+c}+\dfrac{b^3}{c+a}+\dfrac{c^3}{a+b}&=122.\end{align*}Find $abc$.
problems.solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionDenote $s=a+b+c$. Start with the second equation and add $a$ to the first term, $b$ to the second, and $c$ to the third. This will become

\[\frac{a^2+ab+ac}{s-a}+\frac{b^2+bc+ba}{c+a}+\frac{c^2+ca+cb}{a+b}=32+a+b+c,\]which is equivalent to \[s\left(\frac{a}{s-a}+\frac{b}{s-b}+\frac{c}{s-c}\right)=32+s.\]Therefore $9s=32+s,$ or $s=4$. Similarly, in the third equation, add $a^2$ to the first term, $b^2$ to the second, and $c^2$ to the third. The result is

\[s\left(\frac{a^2}{b+c}+\frac{b^2}{c+a}+\frac{c^2}{a+b}\right)=122+a^2+b^2+c^2,\]which yields $a^2+b^2+c^2=6$. Therefore $ab+bc+ca=5$. Now we return to the first equation, and add 1 to each term. The equation becomes

\begin{align*}
4\left(\frac{1}{4-a}+\frac{1}{4-b}+\frac{1}{4-c}\right)=12 \\
\frac{(4-a)(4-b)+(4-b)(4-c)+(4-c)(4-a)}{(4-a)(4-b)(4-c)}=3 \\
\frac{48-8(a+b+c)+(ab+bc+ca)}{64-16(a+b+c)+4(ab+bc+ca)-abc}=3 \\
\frac{48-32+5}{64-64+20-abc}=3 \\
abc=\boxed{13}.
\end{align*}

problems.title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 13
problems.text:
\[\int_0^1 2^{\sqrt x}\log^2(2)+\log^2(1+x)\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Thomas Lam
problems.solution:
Y by ArcheonSince each of these integrals by themselves is really hard, we must use the functions in tandem to try and evaluate this. Noting the exponential with base $2$, we can convert the logarithm to base $2$ as well:

\[\int_0^1 2^{\sqrt x}\log^2(2)+\log^2(1+x)\,\mathrm dx=\log^2(2)\int_0^1 2^{\sqrt x}+\log_2^2(1+x)\,\mathrm dx.\]We now note that

\[y=\log_2^2(1+x)\implies \sqrt{y}=\log_2(1+x)\implies x=2^{\sqrt{y}}-1.\]This inspires us to do the following:

\[\log^2(2)\int_0^1 2^{\sqrt x}+\log_2^2(1+x)\,\mathrm dx=\log^2(2)\left[1+\int_0^1 2^{\sqrt x}-1+\log_2^2(1+x)\,\mathrm dx\right].\]Note that the 2 functions inside the integral are both inverses of each other, so we take a graphical approach. Both functions pass through the points $(0,0)$ and $(1,1)$, and the functions both do not ever go outside the unit square $(0,0), (0,1), (1,1),(1,0)$, so by the reflection property of inverses, the sums of the integrals of these functions comprises the area of the entire unit square. The answer is thus $\log^2(2)[1+1]=\boxed{2\log^2(2)}.$

problems.title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 15
problems.text:
\[\int_0^\infty \left(1-e^{-\pi/x^2}\right)^2\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Vlad Oleksenko
problems.solution:
Y by ArcheonLetting $u=1/x$, we have

\[\int_0^\infty \left(1-e^{-\pi/x^2}\right)^2\,\mathrm dx=\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{u^2}\left(1-e^{-\pi u^2}\right)^2\,\mathrm du.\]Noting the weird $\pi$, we use Feynmann:

\[I(a)=\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{u^2}\left(1-e^{-au^2}\right)^2\,\mathrm du\implies I'(a)=\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{u^2}\cdot 2\left(1-e^{-au^2}\right) u^2e^{-au^2}\,\mathrm du\]\[=\int_0^\infty 2\left(1-e^{-au^2}\right) e^{-au^2}\,\mathrm du=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \left(1-e^{-au^2}\right) e^{-au^2}\,\mathrm du.\]We now use the well-known Gauss Integral $\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-ru^2}\,\mathrm du=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{r}}$ to see that

\[I'(a)=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}}-\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2a}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{a}}\cdot \sqrt{\pi}(1-1/\sqrt{2})\implies I(a)=2\sqrt{a\pi}(1-1/\sqrt{2})+C=\sqrt{a\pi}(2-\sqrt{2})+C.\]Note that $I(0)=C=0$, so our answer is $I(\pi)=\boxed{\pi(2-\sqrt{2})}$.

problems.title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 13
problems.text:
$$\int_0^1 x\ln(x^2)\ln(1+x)\,dx$$

Proposed by Connor Gordon
problems.solution:
Y by This seems to be the only one that hasn't been answered yet, so I'll post my solution. First, note that

\[ \int_0^1 x^n\ln(x)\,dx = \left[\tfrac{1}{n+1} x^{n+1} \ln(x)\right]_0^1-\int_0^1 \tfrac{1}{n+1} x^n\,dx = -\tfrac{1}{(n+1)^2}\]for all real $n>0$. Now, note that $\ln(x^2)=2\ln(x)$ and use the Taylor expansion of $\ln(1+x)$ to get

\begin{align*}
\int_0^1 x\ln(x^2)\ln(1+x)\, dx &= 2\int_0^1 \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n+1} x^{n+1} \ln(x)}{n}\\
&=2 \sum_{n=1}^\infty\int_0^1  \frac{(-1)^{n+1} x^{n+1} \ln(x)}{n}\\
&=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2(-1)^n}{n(n+2)^2}\\
&=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left[\frac{\frac{1}{2}(-1)^n}{n}-\frac{\frac{1}{2}(-1)^n}{n+2}-\frac{(-1)^n}{(n+2)^2}\right]
\end{align*}The first two terms telescope to $-\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{4}=-\tfrac{1}{4}$, and the latter sum converges to

\begin{align*}
\sum_{i=3}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n^2}&=\frac{3}{4}+\sum_{i=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n^2}\\
&=\frac{3}{4}-\sum_{i=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^2} +2\sum_{i=1}^\infty \frac{1}{(2n)^2}\\
&=\frac{3}{4}-\frac{\pi^2}{6}+2\cdot\frac{\pi^2}{24}=\frac{3}{4}-\frac{\pi^2}{12}
\end{align*}Putting this together, we arrive at a final answer of $-\frac{1}{4}-\left(\frac{3}{4}-\frac{\pi^2}{12}\right)=\boxed{\frac{\pi^2}{12}-1}$.

problems.title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 15
problems.text:
$$\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{\sin(\pi x)}{x(1+x^2)}\,dx$$

Proposed by Vlad Oleksenko
problems.solution:
Y by ArcheonThe $\pi$ in the $\sin(\pi x)$ suggests Feynmans.

Let $$I(a) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(ax)}{x(x^2+1)}$$It follows that $$I'(a) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\cos(ax)}{x^2+1}, I''(a) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{-x\sin(ax)}{x^2+1}$$

Note that $$I''(a) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{-x\sin(ax)}{x^2+1} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{-x^2\sin(ax)}{x(x^2+1)} = 
-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{(x^2 + 1 - 1) \cdot \sin(ax)}{x(x^2+1)} = - \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(ax)}{x} + \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(ax)}{x(x^2+1)}$$$$I''(a) = - \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(ax)}{x} + I(a)$$

*Evaluating $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(ax)}{x}$

Letting $u = ax$, the integral becomes $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(x)}{x}$, a well known integral evaluating to $\pi$.

(you use $I(a) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-ax} \cdot \frac{\sin{x}}{x}$)

So, $I''(a) = -\pi + I(a)$

Solving the differential equation gives the general solution $c_1e^a + c_2e^{-a}+ \pi$

Using the fact that $I(0) = 0, I'(0) = \pi$, $c_1 = 0, c_2 =- \pi$

Therefore $I(a) = \pi - \pi e^{-a}$

Our original integral is $I(\pi) = \pi - \pi e^{-\pi}$

problems.title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 10
problems.text:
\[\int_0^1 \frac{(x+1)\log(x)}{x^3-1}\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Vlad Oleksenko
problems.solution:
Y by This solution is shown to me by a friend.

solFirst, note that $x^3 - 1 = (x - 1) (x^2 + x + 1)$. This allows us to rearrange the integral to

\[\int_0^1 \frac{[(x + 1) + x^2 - x^2]\log (x)}{x^3 - 1} \text{d}x = \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log x}{x - 1}\text{d} x - \int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2 \log x}{x^3 - 1}\text{d}x.\]Consider the second integral. We can apply a $u$-substitution $u = x^3\implies \text{d} u = 3x^2 \text{d} x$. Therefore,

\[\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2 \log x}{x^3 - 1} \text{d} x = \frac{1}{3}\int_0^1 \frac{\log u^{1/3}}{u - 1} \text{d} u = \frac{1}{9}\int_0^1 \frac{\log x}{x - 1}\text{d} x.\]This is notably the same as the first divided integral. Hence,

\[I_0 = \frac{8}{9}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log x}{x - 1}\text{d} x.\]The well known power series

\[\frac{1}{1 - x} = \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} x^n\]allows us to rewrite the integral as

\[I_0 =(-1) \frac{8}{9} \int_0^1 \sum_{n = 0}^\infty x^n \cdot \log x\text{d} x =(-1) \frac{8}{9} \sum_{n = 0}^\infty \int_0^1 x^n \cdot \log x\text{d} x.\]To integrate $\int_0^1 x^n \log x\text{d}x$, note that

\[\int_0^1 x^n \text{d}x = \frac{1}{n+ 1}\]which implies by Leibniz that

\[\int_0^1 x^n \cdot \log x \text{d} x = \frac{\text{d}}{\text{d} n} \int_0^1 x^n \text{d}x = - \frac{1}{(1 + n)^2}.\]Therefore, our integral becomes

\[I_0 = \frac{8}{9} \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(1 + n)^2} = \boxed{\frac{4\pi^2}{27}}.\]The summation is well known to be the Basel problem.

problems.title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 11
problems.text:
\[\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin(x)}{2-\sin(x)\cos(x)}\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Connor Gordon
problems.solution:
Let $I$ be the integral in question. $x\mapsto \tfrac \pi2-x$ yields

\[I = \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\cos(x)}{2-\cos(x)\sin(x)}\,dx.\]Adding to the original integral then gives

\[2I = \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\cos(x)+\sin(x)}{2-\sin(x)\cos(x)}\,dx.\]If we let $u=\sin(x)-\cos(x)$, we see $du=\cos(x)+\sin(x)$ and $\sin(x)\cos(x)=\tfrac{1}{2}(1-u^2)$, so the integral becomes

\[2I=\int_{-1}^1 \frac{1}{\frac 32+\frac 12 u^2}\implies I = \int_{-1}^1 \frac{1}{3+u^2}\,du=\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\arctan\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}\right)\right]_{-1}^1=\boxed{\frac {\pi}{3\sqrt 3}}.\]

problems.title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 12
problems.text:
\[\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2} \tan^{-1}\left(\tan^2(x)\right)\sin(2x)\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Vlad Oleksenko
problems.solution:
Integration by parts with $u=\tan^{-1}(\tan^2(x))$ and $dv=\sin(2x)dx$ gives

\[\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2} \tan^{-1}\left(\tan^2(x)\right)\sin(2x)\,dx = \left[-\frac 12 \tan^{-1}(\tan^2(x))\cos(2x)\right]_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}+\frac{1}{2}\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}\frac{2\tan(x)\sec^2(x)}{1+\tan^4(x)}\cos(2x)\,dx.\]The former term can be calculated to be $\tfrac{\pi}{4}$, and writing the latter in terms of sines and cosines (and cancelling the $2$'s) gives

\[\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}\frac{\tan(x)\sec^2(x)}{1+\tan^4(x)}\cos(2x)\,dx=\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}\frac{\cos(2x)\sin(x)\cos(x)}{\cos^4(x)+\sin^4(x)}\,dx.\]The numerator is simply $\tfrac 14 \sin(4x)$, while the denominator is equal to

\[(\cos^2(x)-\sin^2(x))^2+2\cos^2(x)\sin^2(x)=\cos^2(2x)+\tfrac 12\sin^2(2x)=\tfrac{3}{4}+\tfrac 14\cos(4x),\]so the integral becomes

\[\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}\frac{\sin(4x)}{3+\cos(4x)}\,dx\stackrel{u=3+\cos(4x)}{=}-\frac 14\int_{2}^4 \frac{1}{u}\,du=-\frac{1}{4}\log(2),\]and as such the final answer is $\boxed{\tfrac \pi4-\tfrac 14\log(2)}$.

problems.title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 13

\[\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-x^2-4/x^2}\,\mathrm dx\]

Since the function in question is even, rewrite as

\[I=2\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2-4/x^2}\,dx.\]The transformation $x\mapsto \tfrac 2x$ gives

\[I=2\int_0^\infty \frac{2}{x^2} e^{-4/x^2-x^2}\,dx.\]Adding these then gives

\[I = \int_0^\infty \left(1+\frac{2}{x^2}\right)e^{-x^2-4/x^2}\,dx=\frac{1}{e^4}\int_0^\infty \left(1+\frac{2}{x^2}\right)e^{-(x-2/x)^2}\,dx .\]Letting $u=x-\tfrac 2x$ gives

\[I = \frac{1}{e^4}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-u^2}\,du=\boxed{\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{e^4}}.\]

problems.title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 15
problems.text:
\[\int_0^\infty 1+\frac{2}{\sqrt[x]{8}}-\frac{3}{\sqrt[x]{4}}\,\mathrm dx\]

Proposed by Connor Gordon
problems.solution:
Noting that $4=2^2$ and $8=2^3$, the numbers $2$ and $3$ are probably important somehow—let's see if we can get them more involved. First rewrite the integrand as

\[1+2\cdot 2^{-3/x}-3\cdot 2^{-2/x}.\]Seems promising, but the $2$'s and $3$'s are mismatched... how can we fix that? I guess doing $a\mapsto 6/a$ in the exponents would swap the $2$ and $3$, so we can try that. Rewrite again as

\[1+2\cdot 2^{-6/(2x)}-3\cdot 2^{-6/3x}=1+2\cdot {64}^{-1/2x}-3\cdot {64}^{-1/3x}.\]Now they're matched up! Looking a bit closer, these expressions look very similar, just with a $2$ instead of a $3$. Maybe there's some $f(x)$ here... Oh! Noting that $1=3-2$, we can further write this as

\[(3-3\cdot 64^{-1/3x})-(2-2\cdot 64^{-1/2x}).\]This is really starting to look like a Frullani integral... but there's no $x$ in the denominator! What happens if we force one in...?

\[\frac{x(3-3\cdot 64^{-1/3x})-x(2-2\cdot 64^{-1/2x})}{x}=\frac{3x(1-64^{-1/3x})-2x(1-64^{-1/2x})}{x}=\frac{f(3x)-f(2x)}{x}\]for $f(x)=x(1-64^{-1/x})$... whoa! Well now the integral is just

\[\int_0^\infty 1+\frac{2}{\sqrt[x]{8}}-\frac{3}{\sqrt[x]{4}}\,\mathrm dx=\log\left(\frac 32\right)(f(\infty)-f(0)).\]It's easy to see that $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=0$, so we just need $\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x)$. Fortunately, that's not too bad with L'Hôpital's rule:

\[\lim_{x\to\infty} x(1-64^{-1/x})=\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{1-64^{-1/x}}{\frac 1x}=\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{-64^{-1/x}(\log(64))(\frac 1{x^2})}{-\frac{1}{x^2}}=\log(64).\]So the final answer is $\boxed{\log\left(\frac 32\right)\log(64)}$.

problems.title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 1
problems.text: \[\int_1^e \frac{\log(x^{2024})}{x} \mathrm dx\]Proposed by Connor Gordon
problems.solution: Y by sol$\frac{\log(x^{2024})}{x}=2024\cdot\frac{\log(x)}{x}$ and $\frac{d}{dx}(\log(x))^2=2\log(x)\cdot\frac{1}{x}$ so $\int \frac{\log(x^{2024})}{x} \mathrm dx=1012\log(x)^2$ so the answer is $\boxed{1012}$

problems.title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 2
problems.text: \[\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)|+|\cos(\pi x)|\mathrm dx\]Proposed by Anagh Sangavarapu
problems.solution:
Since the graphs of $\sin(x)$ and $\cos(x)$ are just horizontal translations of each other and both of them have a period of $2\pi,$ it follows that

\begin{align*}
\int_0^2 |\cos(\pi x)| \text{d}x = \int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)| \text{d}x.
\end{align*}Therefore, we wish to compute

\begin{align*}
\int_0^2 (|\sin(\pi x)|+|\cos(\pi x)|) \text{d}x &= \int_0^2 (|\sin(\pi x)|+|\sin(\pi x)|) \text{d}x \\
&= \int_0^2 2|\sin(\pi x)| \\
&= 2\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)|.
\end{align*}Then, note that $\sin(\pi x)>0$ for $0<x<1$ and $\sin(\pi x)<0$ for $1<x<2,$ so we have

\begin{align*}
2\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)| &= 2\int_0^1 |\sin(\pi x)| + 2\int_1^2 |\sin(\pi x)| \\
&= 2\int_0^1 \sin(\pi x) - 2\int_1^2 \sin(\pi x) \\
&= 2\left[-\frac{\cos(\pi x)}{\pi} \Big|_0^1\right] - 2\left[-\frac{\cos(\pi x)}{\pi}\Big|_1^2\right] \\
&= 2\left[-\frac{\cos(\pi)}{\pi}+\frac{\cos(0)}{\pi}\right]-2\left[-\frac{\cos(2\pi)}{\pi}+\frac{\cos(\pi)}{\pi}\right] \\
&= 2\left[\frac{1}{\pi}+\frac{1}{\pi}\right]-2\left[-\frac{1}{\pi}+\left(-\frac{1}{\pi}\right)\right] \\
&= 2 \cdot \frac{2}{\pi} - 2 \cdot \left(-\frac{1}{\pi}-\frac{1}{\pi}\right) \\
&= \frac{4}{\pi}-2\cdot\left(-\frac{2}{\pi}\right) \\
&=  \frac{4}{\pi}-\left(-\frac{4}{\pi}\right)\\
&= \frac{4}{\pi} + \frac{4}{\pi} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{8}{\pi}}.
\end{align*}$\square$

problems.title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 3
problems.text: \[\int_0^1 \frac{\log(x)}{\sqrt x}\mathrm dx\]Proposed by Robert Trosten
problems.solution:
We proceed with integration by parts.



Let $$u=\log(x), \text{d}v=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}.$$Then, it follows that $$\text{d}u=\frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x, v=2\sqrt{x}.$$

Thus, we have

\begin{align*}
\int_0^1 \frac{\log(x)}{\sqrt x} \ \text{d}x &= \int_0^1 u \ \text{d}v \\
&= uv \Big|_0^1 - \int_0^1 v \ \text{d}u \\
&= 2\log(x)\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1 - \int_0^1 2\sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x.
\end{align*}Note that

$$\lim_{x \to 0} 2\log(x)\sqrt{x} = 0,$$so we have

\begin{align*}
2\log(x)\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1 - \int_0^1 2\sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x &= 2\log(1)\sqrt{1} -\lim_{x \to 0}2\log(x)\sqrt{x} -  \int_0^1 \frac{2}{\sqrt{x}} \ \text{d}x \\
&= 2\cdot0\cdot1-0-\left[4\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1\right] \\
&= 0-(4\sqrt{1}-4\sqrt{0}) \\
&= -4\cdot1+4\cdot0 \\
&= -4 + 0 \\
&= \boxed{-4}.
\end{align*}$\square$
